"Predict the product for the following reaction: First reactant: CC(=O)C1=C(O)C=CC(Cl)=C1, second reactant: [H]C(=O)C1=CC=CC=C1, Temperature: 80°C, Time: unknown hours, Catalyst: unknown, Solvent: ethanol. Also the procedure of the reaction was the following: General procedure: To a microwave reactor test tube containing ethanol (5 mL), an equimolar mixture of 2’-hydroxyacetophenone 1 (1 mmol) and the appropriate benzaldehyde 2 (1 mmol) were added. Then, 4 mmol of NaOH (from 40% aqueous NaOH solution) was added to the mixture, and it was homogenized by vortex mixing. The resulting reaction mixture was placed inside the microwave reactor (Milestone RotoSYNTH Microwave Reactor) usingthe single reaction vessel accessory and heated to 80 C for 5 minutes. After the firstirradiation, 1mL of 3-6% aqueous H2O2 stock solution (corresponds to approximately1.8 mmol) was added portion-wise and reheated to 80 C by another round of microwave irradiation. The resulting crude mixture was added into crushed ice and acidified(pH 3-5) by adding dilute HCl solution to form pale yellow to brown solids. The formed solids were collected by vacuum filtration, washed with ice-cold water, anddried in vacuum. The dried crude product was then recrystallized from ethanol/water toafford pure 3-hydroxyflavone 3. Performing the reaction at 80 C gave the best yieldand no improvement in the yields was observed at higher temperatures. Decompositionof peroxide does not appear to be an issue, since similar yields were obtained at elevatedtemperatures. All of the compounds of this study were known materials, identified onthe basis of matching their melting points with literature values from the referencescited in Table 2. Further characterization data are provided below. In each case, theanalytical data matched the literature in the cited references The SMILES answer is : OC1=C(C=C(Cl)C=C1)C(=O)C=CC1=CC=CC=C1

"
"Predict the product for the following reaction: First reactant: CC(=O)C1=CC=CC=C1Cl, second reactant: [H]C(=O)C1=CC=CC=C1, Temperature: 20; 20°C, Time: 0.166667 hours, Catalyst: unknown, Solvent: ethanol; water; ethanol; water. Also the procedure of the reaction was the following: General procedure: The substituted aryl methyl ketone (1.0 mmol), an aqueous solution of 10% sodium hydroxide (2.5 mmol) and ethanol (5 mL) were charged into a 50 mL flask, and the mixture was stirred at room temperature for 10 min, followed by addition of substituted aryl aldehyde (1.05 mmol). The reaction mixture was then stirred at room temperature and monitored using TLC with 5% ethyl acetate/petroleum ether as the solvent system until all reactants disappeared. The mixture was extracted with ethyl acetate three times, and the combined organic phase was dried over sodium sulfate and concentrated under vacuum. The residue was recrystallized from anhydrous ethanol, except for 39i and 39a, which were directly used in the next step without purification. The SMILES answer is : ClC1=C(C=CC=C1)C(=O)\C=C\C1=CC=CC=C1

"
"Predict the product for the following reaction: First reactant: CC(=O)C1=CC=CC=C1Cl, second reactant: [H]C(=O)C1=CC=CC=C1, Temperature: unknown°C, Time: unknown hours, Catalyst: unknown, Solvent: ethanol; water. Also the procedure of the reaction was the following: General procedure: All syntheses were carried out in the same fashion. Each reaction was monitored by TLC for 24 h to determine when the starting materials had been consumed. All TLC analyses were run on Selecto Scientific flexible silica gel-coated plates containing a fluorescent indicator and were developed using a hexanes-ethyl acetate (4:1) solution as the eluent. The following procedure is representative of the synthesis of all chalcones (see [Chart 1] and [Chart 2] for structures): A 25-mL round-bottomed flask was charged with the appropriate derivatives of both acetophenone (3 mmol) and benzaldehyde (3 mmol), and mixed with 10 mL of 95% EtOH. The mixture was then stirred magnetically while being gently heated (in a 30 C water bath) until both starting materials dissolved. In a separate flask, NaOH (3.5 mmol) was added to 10-mL of an ethanol-water (1:1) and the mixture was stirred magnetically until the solid dissolved. The NaOH solution was then added dropwise (using a Pasteur pipet) to the ethanolic solution of acetophenone and benzaldehyde described above. In most cases, the reaction mixture turned yellow and solidified within a few minutes. Ice water (2 mL) was added to the flask and the mixture was stirred vigorously. The solid was collected on a Hirsch funnel, washed with cold water, and air-dried overnight. The purity of the crude product was determined at this point using a combination of TLC analysis, melting point measurement, and 1H NMR spectroscopy. In case of an oily product, the reaction mixture was extracted with two 10-mL portions of CH2Cl2 and the organic phase was collected, dried over Na2SO4, and removed using a rotary evaporator. The purity of the oily product was then determined as described above. All impure products (solid or oil) were purified by column chromatography using Merck Silica gel (grade 60, 230-400 mesh) and 4:1 hexanes-ethyl acetate as eluent. In case of a solid, chromatographic separation was followed by recrystallization from either methanol or ethanol-water mixture. In all cases, the purity of the final product was checked again as described above; the spectral characteristics were found to be in good general agreement with those found in the literature.4 The organic chalcones prepared for this study were either pale-yellow solids or oils of the same color (as specified); the ferrocenyl analogs were reddish-orange solids or oils. For each of the reported compounds below, the 1H NMR data is presented as δ (multiplicity, integral ratio), and the IR data as νCO, νCC. The following % yield and physical data are for new chalcones prepared for this study. Data for other chalcones (not given below) have been reported elsewhere[4], [5] and [6] and are also available online as Supplementary data. The SMILES answer is : ClC1=C(C=CC=C1)C(=O)\C=C\C1=CC=CC=C1

"
"Predict the product for the following reaction: First reactant: CC(=O)C1=CC=CC=C1Cl, second reactant: [H]C(=O)C1=CC=CC=C1, Temperature: unknown°C, Time: 11 hours, Catalyst: unknown, Solvent: 1,4-dioxane. Also the procedure of the reaction was the following: General procedure: A mixture of PPh3 (524 mg, 2.0 mmol, 1.0 equiv), I2 (507 mg, 2.0 mmol, 1.0 equiv) and 1,4-dioxane (4 mL) was stirred at rt for 30 min. Then, compounds 1 (2.0 mmol) and 2 (2.4 mmol) were added to the mixture, and stirred for appropriate time (Tabel 2) under reflux temperuture. After completion of the reaction (TLC), DCM (20 mL) was added and the solution was washed with NaS2O3 (20 mL, 10%). Then, organic layer was washed with water (2 × 20 mL) and brine (2 × 20 mL) and was dried over anhyd. MgSO4. The organic layer was concentrated under reduced pressure and the crude product was purified by column chromatography to afford the corresponding product 3. The SMILES answer is : ClC1=C(C=CC=C1)C(=O)\C=C\C1=CC=CC=C1

"
"Predict the product for the following reaction: First reactant: CC(=O)C1=C(O)C=CC2=CC=CC=C12, second reactant: [H]C(=O)C1=CC=CC=C1, Temperature: 20°C, Time: 20 hours, Catalyst: unknown, Solvent: ethanol. Also the procedure of the reaction was the following: General procedure: NaOH (1.20 g, 0.030 mol) was added to the substituted benzaldehyde (0.010 mol) and the substituted 2’-hydroxyacetophenone (0.010 mol) in EtOH (30 mL) solution at room temperature. This reaction mixture was stirred for 20 h at room temperature. The mixture was poured into conc HCl (10 mL) and crash ice (about 150 g), then the mixture was stirred for 30 min. Most of substituted 2’-hydroxychalcone was displayed as precipitate, and it was filtered using suction filtration. The solid residue was purified with recrystallization afforded pure substituted 2’-hydroxychalcone. On the other hand, when the substituted 2’-hydroxychalcone was an oily substance, the HCl solution was extracted with EtOAc (200 mL), washed with brine, dried over anhydrous Na2SO4, and the solvent was removed under reduced pressure. This oily residue was purified with flash column chromatography and afforded pure substituted 2’-hydroxychalcones. The SMILES answer is : OC1=C(C(=O)\C=C\C2=CC=CC=C2)C2=C(C=CC=C2)C=C1

"
"Predict the product for the following reaction: First reactant: CC(=O)C1=C(O)C=CC2=CC=CC=C12, second reactant: [H]C(=O)C1=CC=CC=C1, Temperature: 20°C, Time: unknown hours, Catalyst: unknown, Solvent: methanol. Also the procedure of the reaction was the following: General procedure: For synthesis of chalcones we have used 2 different methods. Chalcones 1-30 were synthesized by method A and chalcones 31-44 were synthesized by method B. For Method B we used LiOHinstead of usual base NaOH for Claisen-Schmidt synthesis and the reaction was carried out in an ultrasonic bath. The general reaction scheme is depicted in Scheme 1.Method A: 20% NaOH (5 ml) was added dropwise to a previously cooled mixture of 5 mmol of selected acetophenone and 5 mmol of selected benzaldehyde in 25 ml ethanol under vigorous stirring. The mixture was stirred at room temperature for 24-72 h. After completion of the reaction as indicated by TLC, the mixture was poured onto crushed ice and acidified with dilute HCl. Precipitated product was filtered by suction and washed to neutral. The solid was recrystallised from dilute ethanol to get crystalline chalcone.Method B: To a mixture of 5 mmol of selected acetophenone and 5 mmol of selected benzaldehyde in 50 ml round bottom flask, 20 ml methanol and 35 mmol of LiOH was added. The reaction mixture was kept in an ultrasonic bath for 1-5 h, until reaction completion was indicated by TLC. The reaction was worked up as described for method A. The SMILES answer is : OC1=C(C(=O)\C=C\C2=CC=CC=C2)C2=C(C=CC=C2)C=C1

"

[13].To a solution of 1, 2 or 3 (1 mmol) in ethanol (5 mL) was addedbenzaldehyde (1 mmol) and a potassium hydroxide 10% solutionin ethanol (10 mL). The mixture was stirred at room temperaturefor 20 min. Then, the reaction was precipitated using water, theprecipitated solid was filtered, washed with H2O (10 mL) and driedunder vacuum to afford the products 4, 5 or 6. The residue was subjected to silica gel chromatographic with petroleum ether/EtOAc (4:1 to 3:1) to give 2. Upon completion of the reaction(monitored by TLC, petroleum ether/EtOAc = 2/1), the slurry was filtered and the residue was washed thoroughly with CH2Cl2. The filtrate was concentrated under reduced pressure, and the solid obtained was crystallized from EtOH or MeOH to give the 21-arylidenepregnenolone derivatives 2a-h. "Predict the product for the following reaction: First reactant: [H][C@@]12CC[C@H](C(C)=O)[C@@]1(C)CC[C@@]1([H])[C@@]2([H])CC=C2C[C@@H](O)CC[C@]12C, second reactant: [H]C(=O)C1=CC=CC=C1, Temperature: unknown°C, Time: 1 hours, Catalyst: unknown, Solvent: ethanol; water. Also the procedure of the reaction was the following: General Procedure: To a solution of pregnenolone 1 (0.316 g, 1 mmol, 1 eq.) in ethanol (10 ml) was added a conc. aq. solution of KOH (2 eq.). Then aldehyde 2 (1.2 eq.) was charged into the reaction mixture to get the corresponding benzylidine derivative 3 (Scheme 1). After completion as revealed by thin layer chromatography (TLC) in an average span of around 1 h, the reaction mixture was precipitated using water because of the limited solubility. The precipitate was filtered, dried and monitored through TLC for the purity. Thin layer chromatography revealed just a single spot which proved the presence of a single product. For further purification, the product was recrystallized from EtOAc:Hexane to give product as solid white powder. It is to be mentioned that when non-aromatic aldehydes were used, the product was formed in a very minor quantity and that too not stable enough at ambient conditions. Thus the study was restricted to the use of aromatic aldehydes only. The spectral data of various compounds (Table 1) is given as under (Most of the peaks due to steroidal skelton were merged and could not be differentiated in the 1H NMR. Thus δ values of only those peaks that distinguish the product and could easily be differentiated are reported as under): The SMILES answer is : [H][C@@]12CC[C@H](C(=O)\C=C\C3=CC=CC=C3)[C@@]1(C)CC[C@@]1([H])[C@@]2([H])CC=C2C[C@@H](O)CC[C@]12C

"Predict the product for the following reaction: First reactant: [H][C@@]12CC[C@H](C(C)=O)[C@@]1(C)CC[C@@]1([H])[C@@]2([H])CC=C2C[C@@H](O)CC[C@]12C, second reactant: [H]C(=O)C1=CC=CC=C1, Temperature: unknown°C, Time: unknown hours, Catalyst: unknown, Solvent: ethanol; water. Also the procedure of the reaction was the following: General procedure: To a solution of pregnenolone 1 (0.316 g, 1 mmol, 1 eq.) in ethanol(10 ml) was added a conc. aq. solution of KOH (2 eq.). Thenaldehyde 2 (1.2 eq.) was charged into the reaction mixture to getthe corresponding benzylidine derivative 3. After completion, thereaction mixture was precipitated with water. The precipitatewas filtered, dried and recrystallized from EtOAc:Hexane to giveproduct as solid white powder. It is to be mentioned that whennon-aromatic aldehydes were used, the product was formed in avery minor quantity and that too not stable enough at ambientconditions. Thus the study was restricted to the use of aromaticaldehydes only. The condensation product 3 (1.0 g, 2.4 mmol)was refluxed in ethanol in the presence of hydrazine hydrate(0.24 g, 4.8 mmol) so as to yield the desired pyrazolines. Howeverthe products thus obtained were very unstable and they decomposedeven at ambient temperature conditions probably because of the inherent instability associated with pyrazolines. The solventthus used was replaced by acetic acid so as to ensure the formationof N-acetyl pyrazoline 4 (0.99 g, 2.2 mmol, 90%) which was highlystable. The product was precipitated by charging the reaction massinto excessive amounts of ice-cold water. After filtration undersuction, the product was obtained in high yields as colorless powderwhich was later dried in vaccuo. However we observed a diastereomericmixture of pyrazolines which was separated throughthe method discussed in the experimental section to yield thedesired isomer. The same procedure was followed for the synthesisof all other analogs. Spectral data of various compounds is given asunder (Most of the peaks due to steroidal skelton were merged andcould not be differentiated. Thus d values of only those peaks that distinguish the product and could easily be differentiated arereported). The SMILES answer is : [H][C@@]12CC[C@H](C(=O)\C=C\C3=CC=CC=C3)[C@@]1(C)CC[C@@]1([H])[C@@]2([H])CC=C2C[C@@H](O)CC[C@]12C

Also the procedure of the reaction was the following: General procedure: To a mixture of an aldehyde (0.1 mol) and acetic acid(0.1 mol) in dichloromethane (15 mL) was added TiCl4 (0.21 mol). The resulting reaction mixture was stirred at room temperature for 20 min under nitrogen atmosphere. To this was added Et3N (0.25 mol) dropwise over aperiod of 10 min and the mixture was stirred for further 3-4 h at room temperature. When the reaction was complete as confirmed by TLC, the mixture was diluted with water (25 mL) and the organic layer was separated. The organic phase was dried over anhydrous Na2SO4 and evaporated under reduced pressure to afford the corresponding (E)-α,β-unsaturated carboxylicacid (1) in excellent yield and purity. "Predict the product for the following reaction: First reactant: [H]C(=O)C1=CC=CC=C1, second reactant: CC(O)=O, Temperature: 185 - 190°C, Time: 9 hours, Catalyst: unknown, Solvent: 1-methyl-pyrrolidin-2-one. Also the procedure of the reaction was the following: General procedure: A 100 mL, round-bottomed flask was charged with Na2B4O7 ·10H2O (5 mmol, 1.9 g) and heated at 160-180C for 3-4 h untilconstant weight. Benzyl-triethylammonium chloride (5 mmol,1.14 g), DMAP (5 mmol, 0.61 g), Py (20 mmol, 1.61 mL) andNMP (3 mL) were added. This mixture was heated at reflux,under stirring for 2-2.5 h, when benzyltriethylammonium-sodiumtetraborate complex resulted in situ. The solution temperature wasdecreased to 70C and acetic acid (50 mmol, 2.85 mL), andp-chlorobenzaldehyde (5 mmol, 0.70 g) were added. A condenserwas fitted to the flask and the excess of acetic acid was removedby distillation until the temperature in the flask reached 185-187C. The obtained solution was finally heated under reflux at185-190C for 6-10 h (see Table 1). After cooling down, thesolution was treated with water (5-7 mL) and aqueous NaOH(20%) to pH=9-10, and the unreacted aromatic aldehyde wasdistilled as azeotropic mixture with water, until the distillate wasclear. The final solution was filtered off and the filtrate was treatedwith HCl solution 15-20% until pH=1-2, under cooling on ice andstirring for 2-3 h, when cinnamic acid precipitated. The resultedproduct was filtered off, washed with cold water (15-20 mL) anddried in a vacuum oven. Recrystallization from aqueous EtOH orEtOAc:petroleum ether gave pure products as white or yellowishcrystals. In all cases, a good trans-selectivity for the cinnamicacids was observed. The SMILES answer is : OC(=O)\C=C\C1=CC=CC=C1

"
"Predict the product for the following reaction: First reactant: [H]C(=O)C1=CC=CC=C1, second reactant: CC(O)=O, Temperature: 20 - 25°C, Time: unknown hours, Catalyst: unknown, Solvent: unknown. Also the procedure of the reaction was the following: Add 10 grams of benzaldehyde into the reactor, stir, add 6.8 grams of acetic acid, dropwise add 37.44 grams of titanium tetrachloride, dropwise add 23.78 grams of triethylamine, keep the temperature at 20  C ~ 25  C, continue the reaction for 4 hours, ice bath Add 300 ml of water dropwise, stir for 30 minutes, filter, rinse with water three times, 100 ml each time, and air-dry at 60C to 65C until constant weight to obtain 13.2 g of white solid with a yield of 94.78%. "Predict the product for the following reaction: First reactant: [H]C(=O)C1=CC=CC=C1, second reactant: CCC=O, Temperature: 30°C, Time: 4 hours, Catalyst: KF-Al2O3, Solvent: PEG400. Also the procedure of the reaction was the following: EXAMPLE 29 Preparation of 2-methylene-5-[(E)-2-methyl-3-phenylallylidene]cyclopentanone Step A :Preparation of 2-methyl-3-phenylacrylaldehyde 13.78 g (0.13 mol) of benzaldehyde, 5 g of KF-Al2O3 and 5 mL of PEG-400 were added to a 250 mL three-necked flask. At 30C, 5.80 g (0.10 mol) of n-propionaldehyde was added dropwise to the mixture while stirring, and reacted under the controlled dropping speed. After 4 h, the solution was transferred into a separating funnel, and the organic phase was collected, washed with saturated brine to neutral, and dried over anhydrous magnesium sulfate. After removal of most of the solvent, the solution was concentrated and distilled under reduced pressure. The fractions of bp:130-132C/2660 Pa was collected to yield 12.30 g of light yellow liquid product with a yield of 89.0%. The SMILES answer is : CC(C=O)=CC1=CC=CC=C1

"

At 30 C., 5.80 g (0.10 mol) of n-propionaldehyde was added dropwise to the mixture while stirring, and reacted under the controlled dropping speed. After 4 h, the solution was transferred into a separating funnel, and the organic phase was collected, washed with saturated brine to neutral, and dried over anhydrous magnesium sulfate. After removal of most of the solvent, the solution was concentrated and distilled under reduced pressure. The fractions of bp: 130-132 C./2660 Pa was collected to yield 12.30 g of light yellow liquid product with a yield of 89.0%. Following the same steps B and C as mentioned in EXAMPLE 28, a light yellow flaky crystal as the desired final product was obtained with a yield of 66%. Also the procedure of the reaction was the following: The aldol condensation was carried out by taking freshly distilled benzaldehyde (15.8 mmol) along with 40 mol% of the amino acid as a catalyst, 40 mol% of benzoic acid as co-catalyst and n-decane as an internal standard in a three-necked round bottom flask. The reaction was carried out under inert atmosphere at a desired temperature to minimize the oxidation of aldehydes used in the reaction. In order to improve the selectivity for the cross-aldol product and maximize atom efficiency of the reaction, 1-alkanaldehydes (7.9 mmol) were added to the reaction mixture under a controlled condition (1130 μl/h) using a syringe pump. The reaction mixture was colled down to room temperature after completion of the reaction (checked by GC). All the reactions were done in triplicate to ensure the reproducibility of the reaction. "Predict the product for the following reaction: First reactant: [H]C(=O)C1=CC=CC=C1, second reactant: CCOC(C)=O, Temperature: 0 - 25°C, Time: unknown hours, Catalyst: unknown, Solvent: dichloromethane. Also the procedure of the reaction was the following: General procedure: To a mixture of an aldehyde (0.1 mol) and alkyl acetate (0.1 mol) in dichloromethane (15 mL) was added Et3N (0.3 mol). The resulting reaction mixture was cooled to 0 C under nitrogen atmosphere. To this was added TiCl4 (0.12 mol) dropwise over a period of 15 min and the mixture was stirred for further 2-4 h at room temperature. When the reaction was complete as confirmed by TLC, the mixture was diluted with water (25 mL) and the dichloromethane layer was separated. The organic phase was washed with 0.5 M aqueous HCl, water and brine. It was then dried over anhydrous Na2SO4 and evaporated under reduced pressure to afford the corresponding alkyl (E)-α,β-unsaturated carboxylate (2) in excellent yield and purity. "Predict the product for the following reaction: First reactant: [H]C(=O)C1=CC=CC=C1, second reactant: CC(=O)C1=CC2=C(C=CC=C2)C=C1, Temperature: unknown°C, Time: unknown hours, Catalyst: unknown, Solvent: ethanol; water. Also the procedure of the reaction was the following: General procedure: All syntheses were carried out in the same fashion. Each reaction was monitored by TLC for 24 h to determine when the starting materials had been consumed. All TLC analyses were run on Selecto Scientific flexible silica gel-coated plates containing a fluorescent indicator and were developed using a hexanes-ethyl acetate (4:1) solution as the eluent. The following procedure is representative of the synthesis of all chalcones (see [Chart 1] and [Chart 2] for structures): A 25-mL round-bottomed flask was charged with the appropriate derivatives of both acetophenone (3 mmol) and benzaldehyde (3 mmol), and mixed with 10 mL of 95% EtOH. The mixture was then stirred magnetically while being gently heated (in a 30 C water bath) until both starting materials dissolved. In a separate flask, NaOH (3.5 mmol) was added to 10-mL of an ethanol-water (1:1) and the mixture was stirred magnetically until the solid dissolved. The NaOH solution was then added dropwise (using a Pasteur pipet) to the ethanolic solution of acetophenone and benzaldehyde described above. In most cases, the reaction mixture turned yellow and solidified within a few minutes. Ice water (2 mL) was added to the flask and the mixture was stirred vigorously. The solid was collected on a Hirsch funnel, washed with cold water, and air-dried overnight. The purity of the crude product was determined at this point using a combination of TLC analysis, melting point measurement, and 1H NMR spectroscopy. In case of an oily product, the reaction mixture was extracted with two 10-mL portions of CH2Cl2 and the organic phase was collected, dried over Na2SO4, and removed using a rotary evaporator. The purity of the oily product was then determined as described above. All impure products (solid or oil) were purified by column chromatography using Merck Silica gel (grade 60, 230-400 mesh) and 4:1 hexanes-ethyl acetate as eluent. In case of a solid, chromatographic separation was followed by recrystallization from either methanol or ethanol-water mixture. In all cases, the purity of the final product was checked again as described above; the spectral characteristics were found to be in good general agreement with those found in the literature.4 The organic chalcones prepared for this study were either pale-yellow solids or oils of the same color (as specified); the ferrocenyl analogs were reddish-orange solids or oils. For each of the reported compounds below, the 1H NMR data is presented as δ (multiplicity, integral ratio), and the IR data as νCO, νCC. The following % yield and physical data are for new chalcones prepared for this study. Data for other chalcones (not given below) have been reported elsewhere[4], [5] and [6] and are also available online as Supplementary data. The SMILES answer is : O=C(\C=C\C1=CC=CC=C1)C1=CC=C2C=CC=CC2=C1

"

Also the procedure of the reaction was the following: General procedure: An appropriate equi-molar quantities of aryl methyl ketones (2 mmol), substituted benzaldehydes (2 mmol) and Fly-ash:H2SO4 (0.75 g) were taken in Borosil tube and tightly capped. The mixture was subjected to microwave heated for 5-6 min in a microwave oven (Scheme 1) (LG Grill, Intellowave, Microwave Oven, 160-800 W) and then cooled to room temperature. The organic layer was separated with dichloromethane and the solid product was obtained on evaporation. The solid, on recrystallization with benzene-hexane mixture gave glittering pale yellow solid. The insoluble catalyst was recycled by washing the solid reagent remained on the filter by ethyl acetate (8 mL) followed by drying in an oven at 100 C for 1 h and it was made reusable for further reactions. "Predict the product for the following reaction: First reactant: OC1=CC=C(C=O)C=C1, second reactant: COC1=CC=C(C(C)=O)C(OC)=C1, Temperature: 20°C, Time: 2 hours, Catalyst: unknown, Solvent: ethanol. Also the procedure of the reaction was the following: 2',4'-Dimethoxyacetophenone (1.80 g, 0.01 mol) and 4-hydroxybenzaldehyde (0.01 mol) were dissolved in ethanol (35 ml) and 0.05 ml SOCl2 was added at RT with constant stirring. The reaction was completed in 2 h and the solid obtained was separated by filtration, dried and crystallized in ethyl acetate hexane to provide chalcone 4, (2.47 g, 87% yield), mp 91-92 C, identified as 2,4-dimethoxy-4'-hydroxychalcone by comparison of its mp, IR, 1H, 13C NMR and ESIMS with the reported data ( Guantai et al. 2011 ). The SMILES answer is : COC1=CC(OC)=C(C=C1)C(=O)\C=C\C1=CC=C(O)C=C1

The reaction mixture was stirred at room temperature for 2h. Added water (30mL). The precipitate obtained was filtered and recrystallized from 95% EtOH to yield crystals of chalcones. Catalyst was washed withether and dried for reusing. The solvent of the filtrate was evaporated then followed by chromatography to obtained pure products. "Predict the product for the following reaction: First reactant: OC1=CC=C(C=O)C=C1, second reactant: CC(=O)C1=CC=CC=C1, Temperature: unknown°C, Time: unknown hours, Catalyst: unknown, Solvent: unknown. Also the procedure of the reaction was the following: General procedure: An appropriate equi-molar quantities of aryl methyl ketones (2 mmol), substituted benzaldehydes (2 mmol) and Fly-ash:H2SO4 (0.75 g) were taken in Borosil tube and tightly capped. The mixture was subjected to microwave heated for 5-6 min in a microwave oven (Scheme 1) (LG Grill, Intellowave, Microwave Oven, 160-800 W) and then cooled to room temperature. The organic layer was separated with dichloromethane and the solid product was obtained on evaporation. The solid, on recrystallization with benzene-hexane mixture gave glittering pale yellow solid. The insoluble catalyst was recycled by washing the solid reagent remained on the filter by ethyl acetate (8 mL) followed by drying in an oven at 100 C for 1 h and it was made reusable for further reactions. The SMILES answer is : OC1=CC=C(\C=C\C(=O)C2=CC=CC=C2)C=C1

Also the procedure of the reaction was the following: General procedure: In a typical reaction acetophenone (0.2 g, 1.66 mmol) and benzaldehyde (0.176 g, 1.66 mmol) was dissolved in PEG (8 mL) and to this solution was added 0.225 g KHSO4-SiO2 (20 mol % KHSO4). Then the mixture was transferred to a sealed reaction vessel of Anton Paar Synthos 3000 microwave reactor and irradiated for 6 min at 250 W power. Maximum internal temperature observed was 92-99 C and pressure 5.3-5.7 bar. After cooling to room temperature ethanol (10 mL) was added to the reaction mixture and filtered through a sintered funnel to separate the solid catalyst. The filtrate was concentrated under reduced pressure and the product was recrystallised from the ethanol. The SMILES answer is : OC1=CC=C(\C=C\C(=O)C2=CC=CC=C2)C=C1

"Predict the product for the following reaction: First reactant: OC1=CC=C(C=O)C=C1, second reactant: CC(=O)C1=CC=CC=C1, Temperature: 20°C, Time: 48 hours, Catalyst: unknown, Solvent: ethanol. Also the procedure of the reaction was the following: General procedure: To a dry100 mL round-bottomed flask, semisynthetic acetophenone B or commercialacetophenone C or D (250 mg, between 1.22 and 2.08 mmol)and corresponding benzaldehyde (1.2 equiv.) were added, and thensolubilized in ethanol (5 mL). A NaOH 20% m/v solution (in 10 mL ofethanol) was added, and the mixture was stirred for 48 h. To stop the reaction, 5% HCl solution was added until pH ~ 7, and the mixture wasextracted with EtOAc (3x30 mL). The organic layer was dried withNa2SO4, filtered, and separated by column chromatography using ahexane/EtOAc, obtaining compounds 151-173 in yields between 27and 99%. "Predict the product for the following reaction: First reactant: OC1=CC=C(C=O)C=C1, second reactant: CC(=O)C1=CC=CC=C1, Temperature: 20°C, Time: 48 hours, Catalyst: unknown, Solvent: ethanol. Also the procedure of the reaction was the following: General procedure: All chalcone derivatives (3a-w) were obtained according to proceedings reported by our research group previously,(Mellado et al. 2020, Mellado, Madrid, Martinez, et al. 2018a, Mellado, Madrid, Reyna, et al. 2018a, Mellado et al. 2021) Briefly,250 mg of acetophenone (2.08 mmol) and appropriate benzaldehyde (1.2 equivalents) were solubilized in ethanol (5 mL) and added 10 mL of a saturated NaOH solution. This mixture was stirred for 48 h at room temperature, and, after this time, a 5% HCl solution was added until pH= 7.0 to stop reaction. Finally, mixture was extracted with EtOAc (50 mL x 3) and separated. The organic layer was dried, concentrated and purified using column chromatography in order to obtain the corresponding chalcones. The SMILES answer is : OC1=CC=C(\C=C\C(=O)C2=CC=CC=C2)C=C1

"Predict the product for the following reaction: First reactant: OC1=CC=C(C=O)C=C1, second reactant: CC(=O)C1=CC=CC=C1, Temperature: 20°C, Time: unknown hours, Catalyst: unknown, Solvent: ethanol. Also the procedure of the reaction was the following: General procedure: As outlined in Figure 2, an aqueous solution of KOH (20% w/v,2 mL) was added to a stirred solution of the appropriate acetophenone(1 mmol, 1 equiv) in ethanol (2 mL). The mixture was stirredat room temperature for 10 min. After complete dissolution, arylaldehyde (1 mmol, 1 equiv) was added slowly and the reactionmixture was then stirred at room temperature for 24-72 h. Aftercompletion, the mixture was cooled to 0 C on an ice bath and acidifiedwith HCl (10% v/v aqueous solution). In most cases, the productsprecipitated out upon acidification with HCl. The crudeproduct was filtered and further purified by recrystallization fromethanol. In the cases in which no precipitate formed, the mixturewas extracted with ethyl acetate and washed with brine and water.After drying over Na2SO4, the solvent was removed by rotary evaporationto give the crude product which was further purified byeither recrystallization or automated medium performance liquidchromatography, eluting with an ethyl acetate/hexanes gradient(0-60%). The SMILES answer is : OC1=CC=C(\C=C\C(=O)C2=CC=CC=C2)C=C1

Aftercooling to room temperature, ice water (250 mL) was addedto the reaction mixture and filtered through a generallaboratory filter paper to separate the solid catalyst.Hydrochloric acid (2 mol L-1) was added to the filtrate untilthe pH was 1-2 and the mixture was refrigerated at 4 C for20 min. Also the procedure of the reaction was the following: General procedure: A solution of substituted acetophenones (5 mM) and aromatic aldehyde (5 mM) in methanol (15 mL) was cooled to 5-10 C in an ice bath. The cooled solution was treated with adding a small portion of pulverized KOH (10 mM). The reaction mixture was magnetically stirred for 60 min and then left overnight or longer, monitored by thin layer chromatography using developing solvent n-hexane-acetone (5-1). The resulting dark solution was diluted with ice water and carefully acidified using dilute hydrochloric acid. The chalcone which separated as a yellow solid was collected by filtration after washing with water and further purified by crystallization from methanol or by silica gel column chromatography. "Predict the product for the following reaction: First reactant: OC1=CC=C(C=O)C=C1, second reactant: CC(=O)C1=CC=CC=C1, Temperature: 20°C, Time: 24 hours, Catalyst: unknown, Solvent: ethanol; water. Also the procedure of the reaction was the following: General procedure: In a flask, 4.1 mmol of 4-hydroxybenzaldehyde (0.5 g) and 4.1 mmol of the ketone compound (acetophenone, acetofuran and thioacethofuran) were dissolved in ethanol. 4.1 ml of 10% KOH so- lution was added and the reaction started. by stirring. Nitrogen gas was introduced into the reaction flask with a balloon. The reac- tion was carried out at room temperature under a nitrogen atmo- sphere with stirring for 24 h. After 24 h, the reaction was checked by thin layer chromatography (TLC) to determine the end of the reaction. The alcalinity was neutralized by adding 10 mL of a di- lute HCl solution to the solution in an ice bath. Pure water was added to the reaction mixture to precipitate the synthesized com- pound. The resulting material was purified by column chromatog- raphy with ethylacetate and hexane (1:5) [45-48] . Three chalcone compounds were synthesized in this way can be seen in Fig. 1. 2.4.2. (E)-3-(4-hydroxyphenyl)-1-phenylprop-2-en-1-one, 1 mp 191 C, 309.1 mg, 33.6% chemical yield. Also the procedure of the reaction was the following: 20) Preparation of 4-hydroxychalcone STR29 2.2 g (18 mmol) of acetophenone and 1.8 g (15 mmol) of 4-hydroxybenzaldehyde were added to a solution of 12 g of sodium hydroxide in 10 ml of water and 5 ml of ethanol. "Predict the product for the following reaction: First reactant: OC1=CC=C(C=O)C=C1, second reactant: CC(=O)C1=CC=CC=C1, Temperature: 20; 20°C, Time: 0.166667 hours, Catalyst: unknown, Solvent: ethanol; ethanol. Also the procedure of the reaction was the following: General procedure: A total of 46 chalcones with different electron-donating and electron-withdrawing substituents (chalcones1-46, Table 1) were synthesisedby following a Claisen-Schmidt condensation reaction. All solvents and reagents were purchased from Merck and Sigma-Aldrich, MO, USA and used without further purification. Briefly, sodium hydroxide (3 eq) was added to a solution of substituted acetophenone (1.0eq) in ethanol followed by the addition of the substituted benzaldehydes (1.2 eq) after 10 minutes and stirred at room temperature overnight under nitrogen. The reaction mixture was then cooled in an ice bath and neutralisedwith 1M hydrochloric acid. The neutralised mixture was then extracted using ethyl acetate. The organic layer was washed with distilled water, dried with anhydrous sodium sulphate, concentrated and the resultant mixture was purified through a column of silica gel to obtain the pure compounds.Column chromatography was performed on silica gel (Merck, Kieselgel 60, 230-400mesh) with hexane:ethyl acetate as the mobile phase. The thin layer chromatography was performed on silica gel plates (Merck, Kieselgel 60, 0.25mm thickness) with F254 as the indicator. The plate was observed under UV light (254nm and 366nm). Melting points of the chalcones were determined using Mel-Temp II melting point instrument. NMR spectra were recorded using a Jeol ECA 400 (400MHz) and/or Lambda 400 (400MHz) spectrometers with trimethylsilane (TMS) esters as the internal standard. All chemical shifts are reported in ppm. The SMILES answer is : OC1=CC=C(\C=C\C(=O)C2=CC=CC=C2)C=C1

"
"Predict the product for the following reaction: First reactant: OC1=CC=C(C=O)C=C1, second reactant: CC(=O)C1=CC=CC=C1, Temperature: unknown°C, Time: unknown hours, Catalyst: unknown, Solvent: ethanol; water. Also the procedure of the reaction was the following: (0.1 mol) Acetophenone (0.1 mol) and p-hydroxy benzaldehyde (0.1 mol) was stirred in ethanol (50 mL). Aqueous potassium hydroxide solution (15 mL, 30%) was then added to the reactants. The above mixture was then refluxed on a water bath for 8 h. Thin layer chromatography (TLC) with methanol-chloroform, was used to monitor the reaction. After completion, the reaction mixture was subjected to crushed ice followed by acidification with dilute hydrochloric acid. The precipitated solid chalcone was then filtered and crystallized from ethanol. Yield 87%. m.p. 132-133C. Anal. Calcd for C15H24O2 (Mol. Wt. 236.35): C, 76.23; O, 13.54. Found: C, 76.18; O, 13.47%. IR (KBr): 1752 (C=O), 1626 (CH=CH), 3122 cm-1 (OH). The SMILES answer is : OC1=CC=C(\C=C\C(=O)C2=CC=CC=C2)C=C1

"

Also the procedure of the reaction was the following: General procedure: To a solution, of equimolar amounts of ketone andbenzaldehyde in EtOH (2 mL/1 mmol of substrate), 6M NaOH (4 equiv.) was added. Thereaction mixture was stirred for 24h at room temperature. The precipitate was collected byvacuum filtration, washed with cold water and recrystallized with methanol. "Predict the product for the following reaction: First reactant: OC1=CC=C(C=O)C=C1, second reactant: CC(=O)C1=CC=CC=C1, Temperature: 20°C, Time: unknown hours, Catalyst: unknown, Solvent: ethanol; water. Also the procedure of the reaction was the following: General procedure: Series of chalcones was synthesized by Claisen-Schmidt reaction,according to procedures described by Santos and coauthors, with minormodifications [37,38]. Reactions were carried out at room temperatureusing 5.0 mmol of aryl ketones and 5.0 mmol of aryl aldehydes, whichwere dissolved in ethanol (10 mL). Aliquots of an aqueous sodium hydroxidesolution (1 mol/L) was added as basis. Reactions were monitoredby TLC plates and after appreciable reagent conversions, thereaction medium was quenched in ice-cold deionized water and acidifiedwith an aqueous solution of hydrochloric acid (1 mol/L). The crudeproduct was extracted with ethyl acetate (3 × 50 mL), washed with brinesolution and the combined organic phases were concentrated underreduced pressure [20]. The purification of compounds was performed bycolumn chromatography. The SMILES answer is : OC1=CC=C(\C=C\C(=O)C2=CC=CC=C2)C=C1

The compound of formula (VII) is obtained with a selectivity of 94% The SMILES answer is : CC(=O)C=CC1=CC=C(O)C=C1

"Predict the product for the following reaction: First reactant: OC1=CC=C(C=O)C=C1, second reactant: COC1=CC=C(C=C1)C(C)=O, Temperature: 0 - 20°C, Time: 48 hours, Catalyst: unknown, Solvent: ethanol. Also the procedure of the reaction was the following: General procedure: The corresponding aldehyde (1.0 equiv) and ketone (1.0 equiv) were dissolved in ethanol at 0 C and 10% NaOH (1.0 equiv.) solution was slowly added. After that, the mixture was allowed to warm up to room temperature and stirred for 48 h. The resulting mixture was evaporated to dryness and the residue was purified by chromatography on silica gel eluted with petroleum ether-ethyl acetate to afford the final compound. The characterization data of the synthesized compounds are in the Supporting information. The SMILES answer is : COC1=CC=C(C=C1)C(=O)C=CC1=CC=C(O)C=C1

"
"Predict the product for the following reaction: First reactant: OC1=CC=C(C=O)C=C1, second reactant: CC(=O)C1=CC=C(O)C=C1, Temperature: 0 - 20°C, Time: 4 hours, Catalyst: unknown, Solvent: ethanol. Also the procedure of the reaction was the following: General procedure: Compound 1-24 were synthesized as follow: the mix of acetophenone analogues (1 mmol) and benzaldehyde analogues (1.1 mmol) in ethanol (10 mL) was cooled at 0 C. Thionyl chloride (5 mmol) was added in slowly. After the thionyl chloride was added in, the whole mixture was kept in room temperature and reacted for 4 h. After completion of the reaction, the ethanol was removed under vacuum. The residues were dissolved in Ethyl acetate (20 mL) and deionized water (10 mL) was added in for extraction. The organic phase was kept and washed by saturated sodium bicarbonate aqueous solution (10 mL), saturated saline (10 mL). The solvent was evaporated to dryness under reduced pressure. The crude product was purified by flash column chromatography on silica gel (petroleum ether/ethyl acetate elute) to provide the compound 1-23. The SMILES answer is : OC1=CC=C(\C=C\C(=O)C2=CC=C(O)C=C2)C=C1

Also the procedure of the reaction was the following: General procedure: In a typical reaction acetophenone (0.2 g, 1.66 mmol) and benzaldehyde (0.176 g, 1.66 mmol) was dissolved in PEG (8 mL) and to this solution was added 0.225 g KHSO4-SiO2 (20 mol % KHSO4). Then the mixture was transferred to a sealed reaction vessel of Anton Paar Synthos 3000 microwave reactor and irradiated for 6 min at 250 W power. Maximum internal temperature observed was 92-99 C and pressure 5.3-5.7 bar. After cooling to room temperature ethanol (10 mL) was added to the reaction mixture and filtered through a sintered funnel to separate the solid catalyst. The filtrate was concentrated under reduced pressure and the product was recrystallised from the ethanol. The SMILES answer is : OC1=CC=C(\C=C\C(=O)C2=CC=C(O)C=C2)C=C1

The chalconesprepared according to this method were formed predominantlywith the (E)-configuration.Acetophenones (0.01 mol), benzaldehydes (0.012 mol),8 g alumina, and 4 g potassium hydroxide were homogenizedin a mortar. Then, the mixture was irradiated in areaction vessel of a CW-2000 focused microwave reactor for 100 s after setting reaction power to 150 W. Aftercooling to room temperature, ice water (250 mL) was addedto the reaction mixture and filtered through a generallaboratory filter paper to separate the solid catalyst.Hydrochloric acid (2 mol L-1) was added to the filtrate untilthe pH was 1-2 and the mixture was refrigerated at 4 C for20 min. The crude product was filtered and the residue waschromatographed on a flash silica-gel column using25-50% EtOAc in hexane as the eluent. Also the procedure of the reaction was the following: 16.06 g (165 mmol) of 98% sulphuric acid were slowly added to a mixture of 2 g (16.38 mmol) of p-hydroxybenzaldehyde and 2.23 g (16.38 mmol) of 1-(p-hydroxyphenyl)-1-ethanone in 20 ml of ethanol at room temperature. The reaction was maintained at room temperature for 23 h and the mixture obtained was slowly added to a solution of 10 g of sodium chloride in 33 ml of water at 0 C. The suspension was extracted three times with 16 ml of ethyl acetate and the combined organic phases were washed twice with 16 ml of water. After treating with anhydrous sodium sulphate, the organic phase was vacuum concentrated to dryness to obtain 3.58 g (91% yield, 97.4% HPLC area) of (E)-1.3-bis(p-hydroxyphenyl)-2-propen-1-one. After injection, continue to react for 5 hours and cool to room temperature. Then add the product solution dropwise to 300mL of deionized water, and filter to obtain a wine-red powdery precipitate. The mixture was neutralized with 6 M aqueous HCl solution (pH adjusted to 2). The mixture was extracted with ethyl acetate, and washed with water and brine. It was further purified by either recrystallization or column chromatography to yield pure solid compounds.BF3-Et2O catalyzed: To a solution of aryl ketone 1 (R1 = c) and aryl aldehyde 2 (R2 = c) in little dioxane was added BF3-Et2O gradually at 20 C and stirred for 2 h. The mixture was then extracted with ethyl acetate and washed with water and brine. It was further purified by column chromatography to yield pure solid compound.Synthetic method of compounds 3 (R1 = a-c, R2 = d) was described previously [22]. "Predict the product for the following reaction: First reactant: COC1=CC=C(C=O)C=C1, second reactant: CCOC(C)=O, Temperature: 40 - 45°C, Time: 1 hours, Catalyst: unknown, Solvent: cyclohexane. Also the procedure of the reaction was the following: Embodiments 1 to 4 are the solvent screening experiments in step 1, and the specific operations are as follows: 1. Feeding, adding 500Kg of ethyl acetate, 140Kg of sodium ethoxide and 280Kg of solvent into the reaction kettle, and stirring; 2. Reaction: dropwise add 200Kg of anisaldehyde while stirring, control the reaction temperature at about 45C, after the dropwise addition, keep the temperature at 4045C for one hour, sample and detect, the reference content product is about 95%, that is, the reaction is completed ; 3. Washing and flashing treatment: add water to the reactor, then add 13% sulfuric acid to neutralize the alkali. Then add water, remove the salt in the organic phase, separate the liquid, transfer the organic phase into the distillation still, the temperature of the distillation still does not exceed 90 , remove the solvent, and send it to the flash still to flash to obtain the flash feed liquid, wherein the flash still The temperature is 110125; 4. Crystallization, centrifugation and drying: add 1.2 times the mass of 95% ethanol to the above-obtained flash feed liquid into heat, after fully dissolving (may need to be slightly heated), filter out insoluble matter, place it at 0-10  C for crystallization, and crystallize The process was accompanied by slow stirring to prevent the crystals from becoming too large. After the crystallization is completed, the supernatant liquid is first pumped out, and the solid is transferred to a centrifuge to be fully centrifuged to obtain a near-dry solid, and the solid content is analyzed. The drying conditions are 40C, vacuum drying, continuous 8 hours to no weight loss, and it can be done after the analysis is qualified. Wherein, in Examples 1-4, the solvent and reaction yield used in step 1 are as shown in Table 1. The SMILES answer is : CCOC(=O)C=CC1=CC=C(OC)C=C1

"
"Predict the product for the following reaction: First reactant: COC1=CC=C(C=O)C=C1, second reactant: OC(=O)CC#N, Temperature: 90°C, Time: 0.5 hours, Catalyst: unknown, Solvent: N,N-dimethyl-formamide. Also the procedure of the reaction was the following: General procedure: The corresponding phenolic aldehydes (8mmol) and malonic acid (24mmol, 2.5g) or 2-cyanoacetic acid (24mmol, 2.04g) were mixed together into DMF (5ml) in a tube until complete dissolution. Piperidine (4mmol, 400µl) was added to the mixture. The tube was sealed and placed into a microwave reactor at a constant power (50W) until reaching a temperature of 90C which was then maintained for another 30min. The reaction mixture was then evaporated under vacuum and the desired product precipitated by addition of 50ml of cold diluted aqueous NH4Cl solution. All the precipitates were collected and washed with cold water, then were purified by recrystallization. The SMILES answer is : COC1=CC=C(\C=C(/C#N)C(O)=O)C=C1

"

Piperidine (4mmol, 400µl) was added to the mixture. "Predict the product for the following reaction: First reactant: COC1=CC=C(C=O)C=C1, second reactant: COC1=CC=C(C(C)=O)C(OC)=C1, Temperature: 20°C, Time: unknown hours, Catalyst: unknown, Solvent: ethanol. Also the procedure of the reaction was the following: General procedure: For synthesis of chalcones we have used 2 different methods. Chalcones 1-30 were synthesized by method A and chalcones 31-44 were synthesized by method B. For Method B we used LiOHinstead of usual base NaOH for Claisen-Schmidt synthesis and the reaction was carried out in an ultrasonic bath. The general reaction scheme is depicted in Scheme 1.Method A: 20% NaOH (5 ml) was added dropwise to a previously cooled mixture of 5 mmol of selected acetophenone and 5 mmol of selected benzaldehyde in 25 ml ethanol under vigorous stirring. The mixture was stirred at room temperature for 24-72 h. After completion of the reaction as indicated by TLC, the mixture was poured onto crushed ice and acidified with dilute HCl. Precipitated product was filtered by suction and washed to neutral. The solid was recrystallised from dilute ethanol to get crystalline chalcone.Method B: To a mixture of 5 mmol of selected acetophenone and 5 mmol of selected benzaldehyde in 50 ml round bottom flask, 20 ml methanol and 35 mmol of LiOH was added. The reaction mixture was kept in an ultrasonic bath for 1-5 h, until reaction completion was indicated by TLC. The reaction was worked up as described for method A. The SMILES answer is : COC1=CC=C(\C=C\C(=O)C2=CC=C(OC)C=C2OC)C=C1

Maximum internal temperature observed was 92-99 C and pressure 5.3-5.7 bar. After cooling to room temperature ethanol (10 mL) was added to the reaction mixture and filtered through a sintered funnel to separate the solid catalyst. The filtrate was concentrated under reduced pressure and the product was recrystallised from the ethanol. The SMILES answer is : COC1=CC=C(\C=C\C(=O)C2=CC=C(OC)C=C2OC)C=C1

Also the procedure of the reaction was the following: General procedure: The chalcone derivatives, except for those containing the nitro groups, were synthesized by Claisen-Schmidt condensation between aldehydes and ketones in a base catalysed reaction (Scheme 1). 0.02 mol of aldehyde and 0.02 mol of ketone were added to round-bottom flask containing 40 ml of ethanol. 2.7 ml of 30% aqueous solution of NaOH was then added to the reaction mixture which was then stirred at room temperature for 12 h. "Predict the product for the following reaction: First reactant: COC1=CC=C(C=O)C=C1, second reactant: COC1=C(OC)C=C(C=C1)C(C)=O, Temperature: unknown°C, Time: unknown hours, Catalyst: unknown, Solvent: water. Also the procedure of the reaction was the following: General procedure: Selected acetophenone (10 mmol) and selected benzaldehyde (10 mmol) were added to 50 ml of 5% aqueous NaOH. The mixture was placed in the centre of microwave oven besides a beaker with ice (50 g) and irradiated for successive periods of 10 s, 5-7 min in total, with cooling in between. After irradiation, color of the mixture changed to crimson. The mixture was then poured into 200 ml of ice cold water and neutralized with cold HCl. The precipitate formed was filtered and recrystallized with ethanol to afford the chalcones namely (E)-3-(3,4-Dimethoxyphenyl)-1-phenyl-propenone (1), (E)-1-Phenyl-3-p-tolyl-propenone (2), (E)-3-(4-Methoxyphenyl)-1-phenyl-propenone (3), (E)-3-(3,4,5-Trimethoxy-phenyl)-1-phenyl-propenone (4), (E)-3-(3,4-Dimethoxyphenyl)-1-p-tolylprop-2-en-1-one (5), (E)-1,3-Di-p-tolylprop-2-en-1-one (6), (E)-3-(3,4,5-Trimethoxyphenyl)-1-p-tolylprop-2-en-1-one (7), (E)-3-(3,4-Dimethoxyphenyl)-1-(4-methoxyphenyl)-propenone (8), (E)-3-Benzo[1,3]dioxol-5-yl-1-(4-nitrophenyl)-propenone (9), (E)-1-Benzo[1,3]dioxol-5-yl-3-(4-methoxyphenyl)-propenone (10), (E)-1-(4-Chlorophenyl)-3-(4-methoxyphenyl)-propenone (11), (E)-1-(3,4-Dichlorophenyl)-3-(4-methoxyphenyl)-propenone (12), (E)-1-(3,4-Dimethoxyphenyl)-3-(4-methoxyphenyl)-propenone (13), (E)-1-(4-Fluorophenyl)-3-(3-nitrophenyl)-propenone (14), (E)-1-(4-Fluorophenyl)-3-phenyl-propenone (15) and (E)-1,3-Diphenyl-propenone (16). The SMILES answer is : COC1=CC=C(\C=C\C(=O)C2=CC(OC)=C(OC)C=C2)C=C1

Also the procedure of the reaction was the following: General procedure: The chemical synthesis of curcuminoids was accomplished by aslight modification of the previously reported procedure (Du et al.,2006). Glacial acetic acid (50 mL) was saturated with hydrogenchloride gas for 1 h at 0 C. A mixture of vanillin (3.04 g, 20 mmol, 2.0 equivalent) and the appropriate ketone acetone, 580 mg, for CC3, cyclopentanone, 841 mg, for CC4, and cyclohexanone, 981 mg, for CC5,each containing 10 mmol (1.0 equivalent) was slowly added. The reaction mixture was stirred at 0 C for 15 min, it was slowly brought to ambient temperature and stirred at ambient temperature for 48 h. The reaction mixture was poured into ice-cold water (200 mL). The water (200 mL) and dried. The crude product was purified using silica gel flash column chromatography. Gradient elution (from 30% to 60%ethyl acetate in hexanes) resulted in the isolation of the desired curcuminoids as bright yellow solids in yields of 1.59 g (59%), 3.02 g(79%), 3.24 g (82%) for CC3, CC4, and CC5 respectively (for more details on synthesis refer Supporting information). 1H, 13C-NMR and IR spectra of CC3, CC4, and CC5 (Figs. S1-S6) were consistent with the proposed structure and previously reported literature. The spectroscopic as well as chromatographic analysis revealed that the synthetic curcuminoids were>95% pure. The SMILES answer is : COC1=C(O)C=CC(C=C2CCC(=CC3=CC(OC)=C(O)C=C3)C2=O)=C1

"

"Predict the product for the following reaction: First reactant: COC1=CC(C=O)=CC=C1O, second reactant: O=C1CCCC1, Temperature: 80°C, Time: unknown hours, Catalyst: unknown, Solvent: ethanol. Also the procedure of the reaction was the following: The direct synthesis of 2,5-bis(4-hydroxy-3-methoxybenzylidene)cyclopentanone by the aldol condensation of cyclopentanone and vanillin was conducted in a stainless steel batch reactor with Teflon. For each test, 0.84 g cyclopentanone, 3.04 g vanillin, 0.10 g sulphuric acid and 10 mL ethanol were utilized. Before the test, the stainless-steel batch reactor was purged by nitrogen two times. The mixture of catalyst and reactant was stirred at 80 C for 8 h. Subsequently, the stainless-steel batch reactor was cooled to room temperature with water, and the reaction mixture was quenched with 20 mL of ice water. The reaction mixture was filtered and the solid was washed twice with 10 mL of ethanol (10 mL × 2). The yellow solid obtained was 2,5-bis(4-hydroxy-3-methoxybenzylidene)cyclopentanone. The yield of 2,5-bis(4-hydroxy-3-methoxybenzylidene)cyclopentanone was calculated. The filtrate was analyzed by gas chromatograph (GC) of Agilent 7890B, which is equipped with a HP-INNOWAX capillary column (30 m, 0.25 mm ID, 0.5 mm film) and a flame ionization detector (FID). The oven temperature was held at 40 C for 2 min, increased to 280 C at a rate of 15 C min-1, and stayed at that temperature for 5 min. Nitrogen was used as the carrier gas at a flow rate of 1.5 mL min-1. The conversion of cyclopentanone was determined by gas chromatography. Also the procedure of the reaction was the following: Fifteen grams (81 mmol) of 4-bromobenzaldehyde was dissolved in 300 milliliter of ethanol. The resultant solution was mixed with 10 g (83 mmol) of acetophenone and 15 g (81 mmol) of a 28 % sodium methoxide methanol solution, and stirred at room temperature for 7 hours. After completion of reaction, precipitated solids were separated by filtration and washed with methanol, thereby obtaining 19.4 g of 3-(4-bromo-phenyl)-1-phenyl-propenone (yield: 83 %). "Predict the product for the following reaction: First reactant: BrC1=CC=C(C=O)C=C1, second reactant: CC(=O)C1=CC=CC=C1, Temperature: -70; 20°C, Time: 1; 6 hours, Catalyst: unknown, Solvent: tetrahydrofuran; ethanol; nitrogen; tetrahydrofuran; ethanol; nitrogen. Also the procedure of the reaction was the following: Under a nitrogen atmosphere, acetophenone(12 g, 0.1 mol) was added to 100 mL of THF in a 500 mL three-necked round-bottomed flask, liquid nitrogen ethanol was cooled to minus 70 degrees, and self-prepared LDA (44 mL, 0.11 mmol) was slowly added dropwise to the above reaction solution. In the incubation reaction for 1 h, p-bromobenzaldehyde (22 g, 0.12 mol) was slowly added dropwise to the above reaction solution, naturally warmed to room temperature, and reacted for 6 h at this temperature. The aqueous solution was added to quench the reaction and ethyl acetate was extracted three times. The organic phases were combined, washed with saturated brine three times, dried over anhydrous sodium sulfate, and the solvent was distilled off under reduced pressure. The resulting crude product was separated by silica gel column chromatography in a petroleum ether-ethyl acetate eluent having a volume ratio of 6:1. Elution was carried out to obtain 20.3 g of product P37-1. The product yield was calculated to be 71%. The SMILES answer is : BrC1=CC=C(C=CC(=O)C2=CC=CC=C2)C=C1

"Predict the product for the following reaction: First reactant: BrC1=CC=C(C=O)C=C1, second reactant: CC(=O)C1=CC=CC=C1, Temperature: 25°C, Time: 72 hours, Catalyst: unknown, Solvent: tetrahydrofuran; water. Also the procedure of the reaction was the following: General procedure: Aldehyde (3 mmol), ketone (3 mmol) was dissolved in THF (22.5 mL) and water (22.5 mL), KOH(1.5 mmol) was added and the mixture was stirred at 25 C for 72 h. Then percarbonate (1.5 mmol) and catalyst (20 mol %) were added, the reaction mixture was stirred at 0 C until the enone disappeared (detected by TLC). The catalyst was recovered by rapid filtration and washed with ethyl acetate. The combined organic fractions were dried over anhydrous Na2SO4, and were then evaporated in vacuo and purified by silica gel column chromatography (AcOEt/petroleum 1:10-1:30) to afford the corresponding epoxide. Acetophenone (26g) and benzaldehyde (23g) were added to the mixture under vigorous stirring and then stirred at room temperature for 3h. After the reaction was stopped, the resultant mixture was cooled in the refrigerator overnight and yellow precipitation was got and filtered. The residue was washed until the pH of the filtrate got to 7 and then with cold ethanol (10mL). The crude product was recrystallized with ethanol to yield light yellow unsaturated ketone . The unsaturatedketone (0.048mol) was dissolved in methanol (120mL) in ice bath. The mixture ofH2O2 aqueous solution (30%, 12mL) and NaOH aqueous solution (2mol/L, 12mL) was slowly added to the system under vigorous stirring and then stirred for 2h. White residue could be obtained after the resultant mixture was filtered and washed with water and cold methanol. α,β-Epoxy ketoneswas prepared after the residue was recrystallized with ethanol. Also the procedure of the reaction was the following: General procedure: The unsubstituted/substituted acetophenone (1a-1b, 1 mmol) was dissolved in approximately 10 mL of absolute ethyl alcohol and stirred for 5 minutes in an ice bath, as shown in Scheme 1. The sodium hydroxide (1.1 mmol) was then added portion-wise to the reaction flask. Following that, various substituted aromatic aldehydes (2a-2f, 1 mmol) were slowly added to the reaction mixture and stirred for 24 hours in an ice bath. When the reaction was completed (determined by thin layer chromatography) the reaction mixture was poured into crushed ice and neutralized with hydrochloric acid. The obtained precipitate was stirred for 30 minutes at room temperature and then filtered, washed with cold water/ethanol, and dried to afford the desired chalcones (3a-3k). Also the procedure of the reaction was the following: General procedure: First aqueous (20%) hydrotropic solution was prepared by adding 1 gof NaPTS (solid) in 5 mL of distilled water and then a mixture of (1mmol) aldehyde 1, (1 mmol) acetophenone 2, and 0.05 g GE-ZnO NRswere added in hydrotropic solution. This mixture was stirred for 5 min.under magnetic stirrer and then, the mixture was kept under ultrasonicirradiations at ambient temperature. After completion of the reaction,(monitored by TLC) catalyst GE-ZnO NRs were completely separated bya simple filtration process. The product obtained by diluting the hydrotropicmedium with water was filtered and washed with water (10mL) to escape completely from the hydrotrope. Obtained product wasrecrystallized by ethanol. The recrystallized products were well identifiedby 1H NMR as well as 13C NMR. The SMILES answer is : BrC1=CC=C(C=CC(=O)C2=CC=CC=C2)C=C1

Also the procedure of the reaction was the following: (1) Add acetophenone (12.6 g, 0.105 mol), p-bromobenzaldehyde (18.5 g, 0.1 mol), and 200 mL of ethanol to a 500 mL reaction flask, start stirring, and then add sodium tert-butoxide (14.45 g, 0.15 mol), and stir at room temperature for 8 hours. After the reaction is complete, add 50 mL of pure water to the reaction flask, stir and filter. The filter cake is washed with deionized water and methanol, and then stirred with 30 mL of pure water and 70 mL of methanol for 30 minutes and filtered. After the above washing and filtering steps are repeated twice, the solid is dried to obtain 22.9 g of white solid C73-1, with a yield of 80%. The SMILES answer is : BrC1=CC=C(C=CC(=O)C2=CC=CC=C2)C=C1

"Predict the product for the following reaction: First reactant: BrC1=CC=C(C=O)C=C1, second reactant: CC(=O)C1=CC=CC=C1, Temperature: 5 - 10°C, Time: unknown hours, Catalyst: unknown, Solvent: ethanol; water. Also the procedure of the reaction was the following: General procedure: All the chalconederivatives were synthesized through a base-catalyzed ClaisenSchmidt condensation reaction [22]. A mixture consisting ofacetophenone (1, 0.01 mol) and aromatic aldehydes (2, 0.01mol) in 50 mL of ethanol was cooled to 5-10 C. Aqueous NaOH(70%, 5 mL) was added dropwise with continuous stirring.The resulting reaction mixture underwent magnetic stirringfor 2 h and left undisturbed overnight. Subsequently, neutralizationwas achieved using conc. HCl. The resulting solid productwas collected and subjected to additional purification throughthe crystallization process using ethanol. The confirmation ofthe purity of all synthesized compounds was carried out throughthin-layer chromatography (TLC), utilizing a mobile phasecomprising n-hexane and ethyl acetate. The SMILES answer is : BrC1=CC=C(C=CC(=O)C2=CC=CC=C2)C=C1

"Predict the product for the following reaction: First reactant: O=C1CCCC1, second reactant: O=C1CCCC1, Temperature: unknown°C, Time: unknown hours, Catalyst: unknown, Solvent: diethyl ether; water. Also the procedure of the reaction was the following: A 2-Cyclopentylidene-cyclopentanone. A 2 liter round bottom flask, fitted with a mechanical stirrer, a reflux condenser and a thermometer, was charged with 951 g (11.3 mol) of cyclopentanone and a solution of 38.2 g of potassium hydroxide in 250 ml of water. The mixture was heated with stirring at about 100 C. for 5 hours. After cooling to room temperature 200 ml of diethyl ether was added and the aqueous and organic phases were separated. The organic phase was washed twice with 200 ml of water, once with 200 ml of 10% aqueous HCl solution and twice with 200 ml of saturated brine solution. The organic phase was dried over anhydrous magnesium sulphate. After filtration of the organic liquid, the solvent was removed using a rotary evaporator and 813.5 g of crude product was obtained. This was fractionated under reduced pressure (0.2-0.3 kPa). The desired product distilled at 105-108 C. and was obtained in 73% yield (623 g). The SMILES answer is : O=C1CCCC1=C1CCCC1

The condensation product (97%) was passed through the fixed-bed continuous-flow reactor (described above) filled with 2.50 g of TiO2 at 425 C, together with nitrogen as carrier gas (100 mL min-1; F = 9.09 g h-1; WHSV = 3.64 h-1). A portion of CH2Cl2 (20 mL) was then added to the reaction and the resulting mixture was filtered to allow for the recovery of the catalyst. The filtrate was then collected and the solvent removed in vacuo to give the crude product as a residue, which was purified by silica gel column chromatography using a mixture of EtOAc and petroleum ether (2:8, v/v) as an eluent to give the desired chalcone. "Predict the product for the following reaction: First reactant: O=CC=CC1=CC=CC=C1, second reactant: CC(=O)C1=CC=CC=C1, Temperature: 20 - 25°C, Time: unknown hours, Catalyst: unknown, Solvent: ethanol. Also the procedure of the reaction was the following: General procedure: A solution of 0.01 mol of the aryl aldehydes and 0.01 mol of the acetophenone in 10 mL of 95% ethanol was taken in a 25-mL Erlenmeyer flask equipped with a magnetic stirring bar. To this solution 3.5 mL of 6M NaOH solution was then added with the help of a Pasteur pipette. The reaction temperature was maintained between 20-25 C by keeping the flask in cold water bath. The reaction mixture was stirred for 4-5 h and was subsequently neutralized by 0.1-0.2 N HCl providing the crude product which was recrystallized from rectified spirit. The residue was purified further by column chromatography using hexane-ethyl acetate in ratio the 9:1 as eluent to afford the pure chalcones (Scheme 1). "Predict the product for the following reaction: First reactant: O=CC=CC1=CC=CC=C1, second reactant: CC(=O)C1=CC=CC=C1, Temperature: 20°C, Time: unknown hours, Catalyst: unknown, Solvent: ethanol. Also the procedure of the reaction was the following: General procedure: Curcumin, cinnamaldehyde, doxorubicin, starting reagents,and solvents were purchased from Merck. The series I andII curcumin-cinnamaldehyde hybrids were synthesized bybase-catalyzed Claisen-Schmidt aldol condensation reactionsusing ethanol as a protic solvent. Series I hybrids(1a-6a) were synthesized as previously described by our group with minor modifications [22]. Appropriate acetophenonederivatives (5 mmol) and benzaldehyde (5 mmol)were solubilized in ethanol (10 mL). A 5-mL aliquot ofNaOH ethanolic solution (1 mol L-1) was added dropwiseto the reaction medium, which was submitted to magneticstirring at room temperature. Series II hybrids (1b-6b) weresynthesized as previously described by our group withminor modifications [21]. Cinnamaldehyde (6 mmol) wasadded to a solution of respective acetophenone (5 mmol) inethanol (5 mL). The solution was stirred at room temperaturefor 30 min, followed by dropwise addition of 5 mLNaOH ethanolic solution (1 mol L-1). The progress of thereactions was monitored using thin-layer chromatographyplates examined under UV light at 254 and 365 nm. Allcompounds were purified over a silica gel chromatographycolumn eluted with mixtures of hexane and ethyl acetate.The structure of the compounds was identified by analysisof NMR spectra, which were obtained with a BrukerAvance III 14.095 T (600 MHz) spectrometer. The SMILES answer is : O=C(C=CC=CC1=CC=CC=C1)C1=CC=CC=C1

"Predict the product for the following reaction: First reactant: O=CC=CC1=CC=CC=C1, second reactant: CC(=O)C1=CC=CC=C1, Temperature: 20; 20°C, Time: unknown hours, Catalyst: unknown, Solvent: ethanol; ethanol. Also the procedure of the reaction was the following: General procedure: As shown in Scheme 1 , the required chalcone derivatives (3a-f, 4a-e, 4g, 5a-e, 5h, 6a-f and 6i) were synthesised via aq. KOH catalysed, Claisen-Schmidt condensation reaction [37] between aromatic ketones (1a-d) with the aromatic aldehydes (2a-i) in the ethanol-water medium at room temperature (RT) for 20-24h. To earn the target chalcones, 1eq. of ketone (1a-d) was dissolved in 20eq. of ethanol and stirred for 5min. 10% KOH (1.5eq.) solution was added slowly to the stirring reaction mixture. The reaction mixture was stirred for 15min, and 1eq. of aldehyde (2a-i) dissolved in 20eq. of ethanol was added dropwise. Stirring was continued for 20-24h at RT, and TLC monitored the reaction progress in an 8:2 hexane-EtOAc solvent system. After the reaction completion, excess ethanol in the crude compound was concentrated, and the product was separated from the aqueous fraction by solvent extraction with EtOAc (3 times). The combined EtOAc layer was dried using anhydrous sodium sulphate, and the excess solvent was removed on concentration under vacuum conditions at 45C. The crude product was purified via silica gel column chromatography (silica gel 100-200 mesh size) using the hexane-EtOAc solvent system to earn the chalcones derivatives (3a-f, 4a-e, 4g, 5a-e, 5h, 6a-f and 6i) in 75-94% yields. The products ' starting materials, reaction time, product structure, appearance, yield, and melting point are tabulated in Table 1 . The IR and NMR (1H and 13C) spectrum of the synthesised chalcones are given in the SI file (Table SI 1 and Fig. SI 1-75). The SMILES answer is : O=C(C=CC=CC1=CC=CC=C1)C1=CC=CC=C1

"Predict the product for the following reaction: First reactant: BrC1=CC(C=O)=CC=C1, second reactant: CC(=O)C1=CC=CC=C1, Temperature: 20°C, Time: 12 hours, Catalyst: unknown, Solvent: ethanol. Also the procedure of the reaction was the following: General procedure: In two-necked round-bottomed flasks, mixtures of one of theketones 1a-1c (10 mmol), benzaldehydes 2a-2e (11 mmol) and anhydrous EtOH (50 mL) were prepared. Each solution was stirred at room temperature for 5 min, after which 5mL of NaOH was added (6 mol L1). The reaction was stirred at room temperature for 12 h, and then stopped by adding HCl (5 mL,10%), yielding a yellow precipitate. The precipitate was filtered off and recrystallized from EtOH. The products (3a-3f, Figure 1) were obtained in good yields and identified by comparing spectroscopic data with data in the literature according to previous studies (Maciel Ferreira et al., 2014), see Figure 1. The SMILES answer is : BrC1=CC(\C=C\C(=O)C2=CC=CC=C2)=CC=C1

"
"Predict the product for the following reaction: First reactant: BrC1=CC(C=O)=CC=C1, second reactant: CC(=O)C1=CC=CC=C1, Temperature: 0 - 20°C, Time: unknown hours, Catalyst: unknown, Solvent: ethanol; water. Also the procedure of the reaction was the following: General procedure: The Claisen-Schmidt condensation of acetophenone with substituted aldehydes was carried out for the synthesis of compounds 1a-1g, 2a-2e and 3a-3b by combining 0.1M of acetophenone and 0.1M of aldehyde in 10ml of 95% ethanol (CAS No. 64-17-5) (Bhagat et al., 2006). To the above mixture, a 6ml solution of 0.2M sodium hydroxide (NaOH, CAS No. 1310-73-2) or potassium hydroxide (KOH, CAS No. 1310- 58-3) was added slowly at room temperature. The mixture was then subjected to overnight continuous stirring. A solvent system consisting of petroleum ether and ethyl acetate in a 7:3 ratio was used to monitor the reaction’s progress using TLC. Hydrochloric acid (1M) (CAS No. CAS 7647-01-0) was used to neutralize the resultant solution, and ethyl acetate (350ml) was used to extract it. Finally, column chromatography was used to separate the obtained crude product into its pure components (1a-1g, 2a-2e and 3a-3b).2.6.2. The SMILES answer is : BrC1=CC(\C=C\C(=O)C2=CC=CC=C2)=CC=C1

"

Also the procedure of the reaction was the following: General procedure: The Claisen-Schmidt condensation of acetophenone with substituted aldehydes was carried out for the synthesis of compounds 1a-1g, 2a-2e and 3a-3b by combining 0.1M of acetophenone and 0.1M of aldehyde in 10ml of 95% ethanol (CAS No. 64-17-5) (Bhagat et al., 2006). To the above mixture, a 6ml solution of 0.2M sodium hydroxide (NaOH, CAS No. 1310-73-2) or potassium hydroxide (KOH, CAS No. 1310- 58-3) was added slowly at room temperature. The mixture was then subjected to overnight continuous stirring. A solvent system consisting of petroleum ether and ethyl acetate in a 7:3 ratio was used to monitor the reaction’s progress using TLC. Hydrochloric acid (1M) (CAS No. CAS 7647-01-0) was used to neutralize the resultant solution, and ethyl acetate (350ml) was used to extract it. Finally, column chromatography was used to separate the obtained crude product into its pure components (1a-1g, 2a-2e and 3a-3b).2.6.2. The SMILES answer is : BrC1=CC(\C=C\C(=O)C2=CC=CC=C2)=CC=C1

"Predict the product for the following reaction: First reactant: CC(=O)C1=CC=CC=C1, second reactant: COC1=CC=CC=C1C=O, Temperature: 60°C, Time: 1 hours, Catalyst: unknown, Solvent: neat (no solvent). Also the procedure of the reaction was the following: General procedure: For a typical synthesis, 0.4 g of resin, 0.02 mol of aryl-benzaldehyde and 0.02 mol of methyl aryl-ketone were charged in a 10 mL glass reactor. The reaction mixture was heated in an oil bath at 60 ± 2 C. The ultrasound probe was immersed directly in the reactor. An ultrasonic generator (Bioblock Scientific 750 W) emits the sound vibration into the reaction mixture. Sonification was achieved at low frequencies of 20 kHz (amplitude of 30%). The reaction time was fixed at 1 h. After cooling to room temperature, dichloromethane (50 mL) was added, the reaction mixture was filtered, and the catalyst washed with hot ethanol (50 mL). Solvent was then evaporated and the dried crude products were crystallized from 95% ethanol, except for nitro-chalcones, which were crystallized from acetone, filtrated and finally dried under vacuum for 48 h. The melting points of the isolated products were measured on a Reichert-Heizbank apparatus. The yields of the reactions were determined by gas chromatography on a Shimadzu 2014-GC apparatus using chloroform as solvent. The capillary column was DB-5 and the carrier gas was nitrogen. The SMILES answer is : COC1=C(\C=C\C(=O)C2=CC=CC=C2)C=CC=C1

"
"Predict the product for the following reaction: First reactant: CC(=O)C1=CC=CC=C1, second reactant: COC1=CC=CC=C1C=O, Temperature: 20°C, Time: 48 hours, Catalyst: unknown, Solvent: ethanol. Also the procedure of the reaction was the following: General procedure: Saturated ethanolic NaOH (20 mL) was added under stirringto a solution of acetophenone (3; 250 mg, 2.08 mmol) andappropriate benzaldehydes (4a-w; 2.70 mmol) in ethanol(2.5 mL). The mixture was stirred for 48 h at room temperature.After, the reaction mixture was neutralized withHCl 5% until pH ≈ 7 and extracted with ethyl acetate (3 × 50mL). Then, the organic layer was dried, concentrated, andpurified by flash column chromatography using hexane:EtOAc (1:0-1:1) as eluent, to obtain the correspondingchalcones (5a-w). The compounds 6o-r were obtainedusing acidic media (see Electronic Supplementary Material). The SMILES answer is : COC1=C(\C=C\C(=O)C2=CC=CC=C2)C=CC=C1

"Predict the product for the following reaction: First reactant: CC(=O)C1=CC=CC=C1, second reactant: COC1=CC=CC=C1C=O, Temperature: 20°C, Time: 48 hours, Catalyst: unknown, Solvent: ethanol. Also the procedure of the reaction was the following: General procedure: All chalcone derivatives (3a-w) were obtained according to proceedings reported by our research group previously,(Mellado et al. 2020, Mellado, Madrid, Martinez, et al. 2018a, Mellado, Madrid, Reyna, et al. 2018a, Mellado et al. 2021) Briefly,250 mg of acetophenone (2.08 mmol) and appropriate benzaldehyde (1.2 equivalents) were solubilized in ethanol (5 mL) and added 10 mL of a saturated NaOH solution. This mixture was stirred for 48 h at room temperature, and, after this time, a 5% HCl solution was added until pH= 7.0 to stop reaction. Finally, mixture was extracted with EtOAc (50 mL x 3) and separated. The organic layer was dried, concentrated and purified using column chromatography in order to obtain the corresponding chalcones. The SMILES answer is : COC1=C(\C=C\C(=O)C2=CC=CC=C2)C=CC=C1

"
"Predict the product for the following reaction: First reactant: CC(=O)C1=CC=CC=C1, second reactant: COC1=CC=CC=C1C=O, Temperature: 20; 20°C, Time: 0.166667 hours, Catalyst: unknown, Solvent: ethanol; water; ethanol; water. Also the procedure of the reaction was the following: General procedure: The substituted aryl methyl ketone (1.0 mmol), an aqueous solution of 10% sodium hydroxide (2.5 mmol) and ethanol (5 mL) were charged into a 50 mL flask, and the mixture was stirred at room temperature for 10 min, followed by addition of substituted aryl aldehyde (1.05 mmol). The reaction mixture was then stirred at room temperature and monitored using TLC with 5% ethyl acetate/petroleum ether as the solvent system until all reactants disappeared. The mixture was extracted with ethyl acetate three times, and the combined organic phase was dried over sodium sulfate and concentrated under vacuum. The residue was recrystallized from anhydrous ethanol, except for 39i and 39a, which were directly used in the next step without purification. The SMILES answer is : COC1=C(\C=C\C(=O)C2=CC=CC=C2)C=CC=C1

Then benzaldehyde (5.0mmol) was added. The reaction mixture was remained under stirring during 1h and monitored by TLC (thin layer chromatography) (ethyl acetate:hexane 3:7 v/v as eluent; UV lamp was used to visualize the plates). "Predict the product for the following reaction: First reactant: CC(=O)C1=CC=CC=C1, second reactant: COC1=CC=CC=C1C=O, Temperature: unknown°C, Time: 8 hours, Catalyst: unknown, Solvent: 1,4-dioxane. Also the procedure of the reaction was the following: General procedure: A mixture of PPh3 (524 mg, 2.0 mmol, 1.0 equiv), I2 (507 mg, 2.0 mmol, 1.0 equiv) and 1,4-dioxane (4 mL) was stirred at rt for 30 min. Then, compounds 1 (2.0 mmol) and 2 (2.4 mmol) were added to the mixture, and stirred for appropriate time (Tabel 2) under reflux temperuture. After completion of the reaction (TLC), DCM (20 mL) was added and the solution was washed with NaS2O3 (20 mL, 10%). Then, organic layer was washed with water (2 × 20 mL) and brine (2 × 20 mL) and was dried over anhyd. MgSO4. The organic layer was concentrated under reduced pressure and the crude product was purified by column chromatography to afford the corresponding product 3.
