"Predict the product for the following reaction: First reactant: CC(=O)C1=CC=CC=C1, second reactant: COC1=CC=CC=C1C=O, Temperature: unknown°C, Time: unknown hours, Catalyst: unknown, Solvent: ethanol; water. Also the procedure of the reaction was the following: General procedure: All syntheses were carried out in the same fashion. Each reaction was monitored by TLC for 24 h to determine when the starting materials had been consumed. All TLC analyses were run on Selecto Scientific flexible silica gel-coated plates containing a fluorescent indicator and were developed using a hexanes-ethyl acetate (4:1) solution as the eluent. The following procedure is representative of the synthesis of all chalcones (see [Chart 1] and [Chart 2] for structures): A 25-mL round-bottomed flask was charged with the appropriate derivatives of both acetophenone (3 mmol) and benzaldehyde (3 mmol), and mixed with 10 mL of 95% EtOH. The mixture was then stirred magnetically while being gently heated (in a 30 C water bath) until both starting materials dissolved. In a separate flask, NaOH (3.5 mmol) was added to 10-mL of an ethanol-water (1:1) and the mixture was stirred magnetically until the solid dissolved. The NaOH solution was then added dropwise (using a Pasteur pipet) to the ethanolic solution of acetophenone and benzaldehyde described above. In most cases, the reaction mixture turned yellow and solidified within a few minutes. Ice water (2 mL) was added to the flask and the mixture was stirred vigorously. The solid was collected on a Hirsch funnel, washed with cold water, and air-dried overnight. The purity of the crude product was determined at this point using a combination of TLC analysis, melting point measurement, and 1H NMR spectroscopy. In case of an oily product, the reaction mixture was extracted with two 10-mL portions of CH2Cl2 and the organic phase was collected, dried over Na2SO4, and removed using a rotary evaporator. The purity of the oily product was then determined as described above. All impure products (solid or oil) were purified by column chromatography using Merck Silica gel (grade 60, 230-400 mesh) and 4:1 hexanes-ethyl acetate as eluent. In case of a solid, chromatographic separation was followed by recrystallization from either methanol or ethanol-water mixture. In all cases, the purity of the final product was checked again as described above; the spectral characteristics were found to be in good general agreement with those found in the literature.4 The organic chalcones prepared for this study were either pale-yellow solids or oils of the same color (as specified); the ferrocenyl analogs were reddish-orange solids or oils. For each of the reported compounds below, the 1H NMR data is presented as δ (multiplicity, integral ratio), and the IR data as νCO, νCC. The following % yield and physical data are for new chalcones prepared for this study. Data for other chalcones (not given below) have been reported elsewhere[4], [5] and [6] and are also available online as Supplementary data. The SMILES answer is : COC1=C(\C=C\C(=O)C2=CC=CC=C2)C=CC=C1

"
"Predict the product for the following reaction: First reactant: CC(=O)C1=CC=CC=C1, second reactant: COC1=CC=CC=C1C=O, Temperature: unknown°C, Time: 72 hours, Catalyst: unknown, Solvent: methanol. Also the procedure of the reaction was the following: General procedure: Chalcone derivatives (3a-g) were synthesized following the method described in theliterature. A mixture of acetophenone (1) (0.01 mol) and substituted benzaldehyde (2a-g)(0.015 mol) in methanol (10 mL) was refluxed in the presence of few drops of piperidinefor 72 h [26,27]. The solution was kept in an ice bath until a solid was obtained, and thechalcone compounds were filtered, washed with cold water, dried and recrystallized fromethanol. The results were compared with the literature [28-31]. The SMILES answer is : COC1=C(\C=C\C(=O)C2=CC=CC=C2)C=CC=C1

"Predict the product for the following reaction: First reactant: CC(=O)C1=CC=CC=C1, second reactant: COC1=CC=CC=C1C=O, Temperature: 5 - 20°C, Time: unknown hours, Catalyst: unknown, Solvent: methanol. Also the procedure of the reaction was the following: General procedure: A solution of substituted acetophenones (5 mM) and aromatic aldehyde (5 mM) in methanol (15 mL) was cooled to 5-10 C in an ice bath. The cooled solution was treated with adding a small portion of pulverized KOH (10 mM). The reaction mixture was magnetically stirred for 60 min and then left overnight or longer, monitored by thin layer chromatography using developing solvent n-hexane-acetone (5-1). The resulting dark solution was diluted with ice water and carefully acidified using dilute hydrochloric acid. The chalcone which separated as a yellow solid was collected by filtration after washing with water and further purified by crystallization from methanol or by silica gel column chromatography. The SMILES answer is : COC1=C(\C=C\C(=O)C2=CC=CC=C2)C=CC=C1

"Predict the product for the following reaction: First reactant: CC(=O)C1=CC=CC=C1, second reactant: COC1=CC=CC=C1C=O, Temperature: 20°C, Time: 48 hours, Catalyst: unknown, Solvent: unknown. Also the procedure of the reaction was the following: General procedure: Synthesis of methoxychalcones 5-21 was achieved byClaisen-Schmidt reaction, using protocols reported by ourgroup with minor modifications [16,17]. Appropriateacetophenone derivatives (5 mmol) and respectivebenzaldehyde derivatives (5 mmol) were solubilized inethanol (10 mL), and ethanolic solution of NaOH (1.0 mol/L,5 mL) was added dropwise to the reaction medium, whichwas submitted to magnetic stirring at room temperature.Progress of reaction was checked by thin-layerchromatography analyses. After 48 h, the reaction mediumwas poured onto crushed ice from deionized water.Precipitates were removed by filtration, washed with colddeionized water and dried at room temperature. All crudeproducts were purified over successive silica gel columns,using mixtures of hexane and ethyl acetate as mobile phase. The SMILES answer is : COC1=C(\C=C\C(=O)C2=CC=CC=C2)C=CC=C1

Also the procedure of the reaction was the following: General procedure: A mixture of acetophenone derivative (6 mmol) and benzaldehyde derivative (6 mmol) was dissolved in ethanol (30 mL), then NaOH 40% solution (6 mL) was added dropwise, while the temperature was kept under 10 C, the reaction mixture was stirred under this condition for 1 hour, then the stirring was continued at room temperature for 4 hours. Thereafter the reaction mixture was poured into ice-water; the precipitated solid was filtered off, and recrystallized from aqueous ethanol. For compound 17, the synthesis was conducted according to procedure described by Durst and Gokel [19]. The SMILES answer is : COC1=C(\C=C\C(=O)C2=CC=CC=C2)C=CC=C1

Also the procedure of the reaction was the following: General procedure: A 50 mL round-bottomed flask was charged with the appropriate ketone (3.0 mmol), aldehyde (3.0 mmol) and 10 ml of 95% EtOH, to which a NaOH solution [3.5 mmol of NaOH in 10 mL of ethanol-water (1:1, v/v)] was added dropwise. The mixture was stirred at room temperature. In most cases, a precipitate produced after stirring for several hours. The solid was collected by filtration, washed with water and recrystallized from EtOH to get the products. In the cases that oily products were produced, the solvent of reaction mixture was removed by rotary evaporator, the residue was treated with water (20 mL) and extracted with CH2Cl2 (3×20 mL). The organic phase was dried over anhydrous Na2SO4, and solvent was removed by a rotary evaporator. The residue was purified by column chromatography with petroleum ether/ethyl acetate (15:1-5:1) as an eluent to give products. The SMILES answer is : COC1=C(\C=C\C(=O)C2=CC=CC=C2)C=CC=C1

After the addition is complete, the reaction solution was allowed to stir at room temperature for approximately 4 h. The resultant solution was mixed with 15 g (0.12 mol) of acetophenone and 23 g (0.12 mol) of a 28 % sodium methoxide methanol solution, and stirred at room temperature for 4 hours. After completion of the reaction, the precipitated solids were separated by filtration and washed with methanol, thereby obtaining 34.0 g of 3-anthracen-9-yl-1-phenyl-propenone (yield: 91 %). "Predict the product for the following reaction: First reactant: CC(=O)C1=CC=CC=C1, second reactant: CCCCO, Temperature: 110°C, Time: 12 hours, Catalyst: unknown, Solvent: 1,4-dioxane. Also the procedure of the reaction was the following: General procedure: To a solution of Ir(III) complex (0.02 mmol) and base (1.0 mmol) in solution (3 mL) was added the corresponding ketone (1.0 mmol) and alcohol (2.0 mmol) under nitrogen. The reaction mixture was then placed in an oil bath and heated at 110 C for 12 h, cooled and quenched with water. The organic layer was separated and the aqueous layer was extracted with ethyl acetate, then the combined organic layers were washed with water, dried over MgSO4, filtered, and the solvent was removed on a rotary evaporator. The resulting residue was purified by flash chromatography on silica gel using suitable mixtures of hexane/ethyl acetate as eluent. The products were characterized by comparing their m.p., IR and 1 H NMR spectra with those found in the literature [8], [12], [15], [32] and [33]. The SMILES answer is : CCCCCC(=O)C1=CC=CC=C1

"Predict the product for the following reaction: First reactant: CC(=O)C1=CC=CC=C1, second reactant: CCCCO, Temperature: 120°C, Time: 18 hours, Catalyst: unknown, Solvent: toluene. Also the procedure of the reaction was the following: General procedure: Cs2CO3 (0.6 mmol,195.6 mg) and toluene (1 mL) were added to a Schlenk tube under a N2 atmosphere. [RuCl2(η6-p-cymene)]2 (0.005 mmol, 3.1 mg), L1 (0.01 mmol, 2.8 mg), alcohols (1.1 mmol) and ketones (1.0 mmol) were added in that order and the Schlenk tube was closed and stirred at 120C for 18 h. The reaction mixture was cooled to room temperature, quenched with water and extracted with ethyl acetate (20 mL x 3). The combined extracts were dried over anhydrous sodium sulfate and concentrated in vacuo. The product was purified by column chromatography using petroleum ether/ethyl acetate as eluent to give the corresponding product (Figs. S22-S47 in Supporting Information). The SMILES answer is : CCCCCC(=O)C1=CC=CC=C1

"Predict the product for the following reaction: First reactant: COC1=CC=CC=C1C=O, second reactant: CC(C)=O, Temperature: 65°C, Time: 1.5 hours, Catalyst: unknown, Solvent: water. Also the procedure of the reaction was the following: 2-Methoxy-benzaldehyde (5 g, 36 mmol) was suspended in a mixture of acetone/water (5 ml/5 ml). A 1% aqueous solution of sodium hydroxide (10 ml) was slowly added to the reaction mixture. The reaction mixture was heated to 65 C. and stirred for 1.5 h. The reaction mixture was cooled to ambient temperature, water (20 ml) and toluene (20 ml) were added to the flask. The organic phase was separated, washed with brine and dried with MgSO4. The solution was filtered and the solvent removed in vacuo to give the required product as a yellow powder. The title compound was used in the next step without further purification. Yield: 6.09 g (96%) 1H NMR (400 MHz, CHLOROFORM-d) δ ppm 7.82 (1H, d), 7.48 (1H, d), 7.30 (1H, t), 6.83-6.94 (2H, m), 6.68 (1H, d), 3.83 (3H, s), 2.32 (3H, s). "Predict the product for the following reaction: First reactant: COC1=CC=CC=C1C=O, second reactant: CC(C)=O, Temperature: 20°C, Time: 2 hours, Catalyst: unknown, Solvent: water. Also the procedure of the reaction was the following: General procedure: To a solution of substituted benzaldehyde (80.6 mmol) inanhydrous acetone (100 mL), 1 M NaOH (80.6 mmol) in water wasadded. The reaction was stirred at room temperature for 2 h.Removal of the solvent gave a residue. H2O (300 mL) was added tothe residue. The mixture was extracted with EtOAc (3 50 mL),washed with brine, and dried over Na2SO4. The solvent wasremoved under reduced pressure to obtain compound 6. To a solutionof 3 in EtOAc, 10% Pd/C (0.1 equiv.) was added. The mixturewas stirred at room temperature for 1 h under 2 atm of hydrogen.The Pd/C was filtered and the solvent was removed to yield compound7. HCOONH4 was added to a solution of 7 and 10% Pd/C (0.1equiv.) in MeOH (100 mL). The reaction mixturewas heated to 75 Cfor 5 h. The mixture was cool to room temperature and the solventwas evaporated to yield a residue. H2O (100 mL) was added to theresidue. The mixturewas extracted with EtOAc (3 50 mL),washedwith brine, and dried over Na2SO4. The solvent was removed underreduced pressure to obtain compounds 8-01 to 8-14. The SMILES answer is : COC1=CC=CC=C1C=CC(C)=O

"
"Predict the product for the following reaction: First reactant: COC1=CC=CC=C1C=O, second reactant: CC(C)=O, Temperature: 20 - 65°C, Time: unknown hours, Catalyst: unknown, Solvent: water. Also the procedure of the reaction was the following: General procedure: Substituted benzaldehydes (10 mmol, 1.0 eq) were dissolved in a mixture of acetoneand water, 1% aqueous NaOH (10 mL) was slowly added to the reaction mixture, andthe reaction mixture was heated from room temperature to 65C and stirred uniformlyuntil TLC detection. The reaction of the starting materials was completed. The reactionmixture was cooled to room temperature. A mixture of ethyl acetate (20 mL) and water(10 mL) was added to the round bottom flask, and the organic phase was extracted andseparated. The organic phase was washed with saturated NaCl, dried over anhydrousNa2SO4, and concentrated under reduced pressure. The α, β-unsaturated ketones withdifferent substituents were obtained by column chromatography on silica gel (~75%yield) The SMILES answer is : COC1=CC=CC=C1C=CC(C)=O

"
"Predict the product for the following reaction: First reactant: CCOC(=O)C(=O)OCC, second reactant: CC(C)=O, Temperature: -5°C, Time: 3 hours, Catalyst: unknown, Solvent: ethanol. Also the procedure of the reaction was the following: Sodium ethylate (30.0 g, 0.45 mol) was added into 300 mL of anhydrous ethanol and stirred evenly in ice-salt baths. Then the mixture solution of acetone (14.7 g, 0.3 mol) and diethyl oxalate (46.7 g, 0.32 mol) was added dropwise into sodium ethoxide-ethanol solution to keep the reaction temperature below -5 C for 3 h. The mixture was poured into ice water. After using hydrochloric acid (1 mol/L) to keep the pH around 4, the aqueous phase was extracted with ethyl acetate (EA). The organic layer was washed twice with 150 mL water and dried over Na2SO4, filtered,and concentrated under reduced pressure; 46.5 g (94 %yield, 96 % purity) yellow liquid (1a) was obtained. Without further purification, compound 1a was used in the next reaction. 1b-h were obtained in analogous procedures. The SMILES answer is : CCOC(=O)C(=O)CC(C)=O

"
"Predict the product for the following reaction: First reactant: CCOC(=O)C(=O)OCC, second reactant: CC(C)=O, Temperature: 0 - 20°C, Time: unknown hours, Catalyst: unknown, Solvent: ethanol. Also the procedure of the reaction was the following: General procedure: A mixture of ketone 15(0.087 mol), diethyl oxalate 16(0.087mol),thinly sliced sodium (0.047mol) in ethanol (55 mL) was first stirred at 0 and then stirred over night at room temperature. After complication, the mixture was acidified(pH3.0,with 20% H2SO4), filtered and extracted with dichloromethane.The organic phase was dried and concentrated under vacuum to obtainan yellow or orange liquid 17a-e. The 1,3-diketone 17a-e(0.025mol) was dissolved in methanol (10mL),then added dropwise to a cooled solution(0C) of hydrazinobenzene(0.025 mol) in methanol (30mL). The reaction was stirred for an hour at room temperature, refluxed for 2h,and the solvent was evaporated under reduced pressure. The residual liguid was purified by column chromatography (a5% gradient of ethyl acetate in hexanes over a column of silica gel) to afford immediate 18a-e.To obtain the acid 19a-e, a solution of 18a-e(0.007 mol) was saponified through adding7ml 6 mol/L NaOH and stirring at 80Cfor 2 h.The mixture was acidified (pH1-2) with concentrated hydrochloric acid and filtered to afford 19a-e.To a solution of 19a-e(0.010mol) in 15ml DMF, NCS (0.010mol) was added.The reaction mixture was heated at 90C for 1hand then added to ice water(50ml), and filtered t oobtain 4-chlorosubstituted carboxylic acids 20a-e. The amide derivatives 21-38 were prepared through the acyl chlorides derived from 19 a-e or 20a-e. A solution of 19a-e or 20a-e(0.004mol) in thionyl chloride(10mL) was refluxed for 5 h and then concentrated under vacuum. The crude acylchloride was added dropwise to a cooled solution(0C) of substituted aniline (0.004mol) and TEA (0.008mol)in dichloromethane (10mL). The mixture was stirred overnight at room temperature, and then purified on a column of silica using a gradient of ethylacetate in hexanes to afford the pure products.The yields of imtermediate 17a-e, 18a-e, 19a-e and 20a-e are listed intable 1S. The SMILES answer is : CCOC(=O)C(=O)CC(C)=O

Also the procedure of the reaction was the following: Na (25.3 g, 1.1 mol) was added to anhydrous EtOH (600 mL) within 30 min, and the mixture was stirred atroom temparature for 2 h. Then, a mixture of diethyl oxalate (146 g, 1.0 mol) and dry acetone (58 g, 1.0 mol) was addedslowly dropwise within 1 h. The reaction mixture was stirred at room temprature for additional 1 h, and then was filtered.The obtained filter cake was added into a mixture of ice (500 g) and water (1 L), and then concentrated sulfuric acid wasadded to adjust the pH to 1, extracted with EtOAc. The EtOAc layer was washed with brine, dried over anhydrous sodiumsulfate, and concentrated under vacuum to give the title compound (95 g, 60 %). 1H NMR (CDCl3):δ 6.37 (1H, s), 4.35(2H, q, J = 7.2 Hz), 2.26 (3H, s), 1.38 (3H, t, J =7.2 Hz). Also the procedure of the reaction was the following: Na (25.3 g, 1.1 mol) was added to anhydrous EtOH (600 mL) within 30 min, and the mixture was stirred at room temparature for 2 h. Then, a mixture of diethyl oxalate (146 g, 1.0 mol) and dry acetone (58 g, 1.0 mol) was added slowly dropwise within 3 h. The reaction mixture was stirred at room temprature for additional 1 h, and then was filtered. The obtained filter cake was added into a mixture of ice (500 g) and water (1 L), and then concentrated sulfuric acid was added to adjust the pH to 1, extracted with EtOAc. The EtOAc layer was washed with brine, dried over anhydrous sodium sulfate, and concentrated under vacuum to give the title compound (95 g, 60%). 1H NMR (CDCl3):δ6.37 (1H, s), 4.35 (2H, q, J=7.2 Hz), 2.26 (3H, s), 1.38 (3H, t, J=7.2 Hz). "Predict the product for the following reaction: First reactant: CCOC(=O)C(=O)OCC, second reactant: CC(C)=O, Temperature: 10°C, Time: 4 hours, Catalyst: unknown, Solvent: ethanol. Also the procedure of the reaction was the following: To an ice bath cooled solution of sodium (0.217 mol) in anhydrous ethanol(125 mL), a solution of acetone 15 (200 mmol) and diethyl oxalate 16 (200 mmol) was slowly added. The reaction mixture was allowed to stir for 4 h keeping the temperature below 10 C. Subsequently the mixture was filtered, dissolved in cold water and acidified to pH 3 with sulfuric acid (20%). After the acidification the solution was extracted three times with dichloromethane (each 50 mL), the extracts collected and evaporated under reduced pressure to give the ethyl acetopyruvate 17 (yields 60%). The SMILES answer is : CCOC(=O)C(=O)CC(C)=O

Then, the reaction mixture was filtered; the solids were dissolved in ice-cold water (50 mL), acidified with concentrated sulfuric acid and extracted with ethyl acetate (100 mL). After completion of the dropwise addition, the reaction solution was allowed to stand for 2-4 hours. The reaction solution was poured into ice water, adjusted to pH = 4 with dilute hydrochloric acid, extracted with ethyl acetate, and the resulting organic phase was washed with water, dried over anhydrous sodium sulfate, And concentrated to give ethyl 2 4-dioxovalerate 46. 5 g. 80% hydrazine hydrate (0.38 mol) was added dropwise to the above mentioned solution of ethyl 2 4-dioxovalerate in ethanol (300 mL) over 1 to 2 hours at -10 to 5  C under stirring. After the dropwise addition, the incubation reaction was continued for 1 to 2 hours. After most of the solvent was removed under reduced pressure, ethyl acetate was extracted and the resulting organic phase was washed with water, dried over anhydrous sodium sulfate and concentrated under reduced pressure to give the title compound 31. 5 g. The SMILES answer is : CCOC(=O)C(=O)CC(C)=O

"Predict the product for the following reaction: First reactant: CCOC(=O)C(=O)OCC, second reactant: CC(C)=O, Temperature: 30 - 35°C, Time: unknown hours, Catalyst: unknown, Solvent: methanol. Also the procedure of the reaction was the following: Add 146.1g diethyl oxalate, 58.1g acetone, 54.0g sodium methoxide, and 1100g methanol into a 2000mL three-necked flask equipped with mechanical stirring, condenser tube, and thermometer, and react at 30~35C for 6~8 hours for sampling and analysis. According to the liquid Phase chromatography analysis results determine the end point of the reaction. After the reaction is completed, adjust pH to 3~4 with concentrated hydrochloric acid, remove methanol under negative pressure, add 500g of water, extract the water layer twice with 600g of 1,2-dichloroethane, combine the organic phases, and The phase was desolvated under negative pressure to obtain 159.7g of ethyl 2,4-dikevalerate, which was then reacted in the next step. "Predict the product for the following reaction: First reactant: CCOC(=O)C(=O)OCC, second reactant: CC(C)=O, Temperature: unknown°C, Time: unknown hours, Catalyst: unknown, Solvent: ethanol. Also the procedure of the reaction was the following: Sodium ethoxide ethanol solution is used as the base, and the temperature is controlled. A mixture of acetone and diethyl oxalate is added thereto. Under the action of sodium ethoxide, an aldol condensation reaction occurs to generate the sodium salt of 2,4-dicarbonyl ethyl pentanoate (referred to as triketone sodium salt). The triketone sodium salt is added to water, and the pH is adjusted to 4-5 with hydrochloric acid. Ethyl acetate is added to extract the aqueous phase twice.The ethyl acetate phases are combined, and the ethyl acetate is evaporated under reduced pressure to obtain triketone (2,4-dicarbonyl ethyl pentanoate). The SMILES answer is : CCOC(=O)C(=O)CC(C)=O

"Predict the product for the following reaction: First reactant: CCOC(=O)C(=O)OCC, second reactant: COC1=CC=C(C=C1)C(C)=O, Temperature: 0 - 80°C, Time: unknown hours, Catalyst: unknown, Solvent: unknown. Also the procedure of the reaction was the following: General procedure: This compound was prepared according to the literature reported procedure [2]. Initially, sodium methoxide was generated in situ by portion wise addition of sodium (1.8 g, 0.0799 mol) to ethanol (50 mL). To this a solution of diethyl oxalate (8.76 mL, 0.0799 mol) and acetophenone (5 g, 0.0416 mol) in ethanol (25 mL) was added dropwise at 0 C. The mixture was slowly warmed to room temperature and heated at reflux for 2 h. Progress of the reaction was monitored by TLC (Hexane-EtOAc, 70:30). After completion, the reaction mixture was cooled to room temperature upon which colorless solid precipitated. It was separated by filtration and washed with absolute ethanol. The solid residue was taken up in water (20 mL) and acidified with 1 N HCl solution upon which yellow solid precipitated. It was filtered and washed with hexane to give target molecule as yellow solid in 6.0 g, 66% yield. The SMILES answer is : CCOC(=O)C(=O)CC(=O)C1=CC=C(OC)C=C1

"
"Predict the product for the following reaction: First reactant: CCOC(=O)C(=O)OCC, second reactant: COC1=CC=C(C=C1)C(C)=O, Temperature: 20 - 80°C, Time: 24.5 hours, Catalyst: unknown, Solvent: ethanol. Also the procedure of the reaction was the following: General procedure: A mixture of acetophenone derivatives 1 (10 mmol) and diethyl oxalate 2 (10 mmol) was added to freshly prepared solu- tion EtONa/EtOH (10 mmol Na in 10 mL ethanol) in a dropwise manner at room temperature and obtained mixture was stirred at room temperature for 24 h. Then, diethyloxalate (1, 125 mmol of) was added dropwise to the in situprepared sodium ethoxide, and the mixture was stirred for 1h in an ice bath, followed by dropwise addition of theethanol solution of desired acetophenone (2, 50 mmol). Themixture was stirred for 24-48 h at room temperature, andthen the pH was adjusted to 2 using sulfuric acid solution(5%) when the completion of the reaction was checked byTLC (ethyl acetate/n-hexane:1/10). The combined organic layer was dried over anhydrous MgSO4 and distilled on rotary evaporator. The crude product was used for further reaction. "Predict the product for the following reaction: First reactant: COC1=CC=C(C=O)C(OC)=C1, second reactant: COC1=CC=C(C=C1)C(C)=O, Temperature: 20°C, Time: unknown hours, Catalyst: unknown, Solvent: ethanol; water. Also the procedure of the reaction was the following: Claisen-Schmidt condensation. To a solution of substituted acetophenone (100 mg) and substituted benzaldehyde (1.2 eq) in a mixed solvent of EtOH and H2O (v/v, 2:1, 5 mL) at room temperature, NaOH aqueous solution (1 mol/L, 0.5 mL) was added dropwise. The result mixture was stirred overnight and the reaction process was monitored by TLC (5:1, PE/EA). Then, the reaction was quenched with 20 mL water, and extracted with DCM (2×10 mL). The organic layer was dried over Na2SO4 and concentrated in vacuo. The residue was purified by column chromatography on silica gel to afford chalcone derivatives. For products 3a and 3b, acetone 1a (10 mmol) and the corresponding aldehydes 2a or 2b (20 mmol) were used, respectively. The products 3c-e were prepared from the appropriate ketone 1b or 1c (10 mmol) and the corresponding aldehyde 2a or 2b (11 mmol). Finally, the product 3f was synthesized from acetone 1a (10 mmol) and aldehyde 2b (5 mmol). The reactions were stirred at room temperature for 6 h, after which an aqueous 10 % HCl solution (10 mL) was added, yielding yellow precipitates. Then, 0.2 mmol of L-proline was added tothe reaction system as a catalyst, and the mixture was stirred at roomtemperature overnight. The organic layer was enriched and dried withanhydrous Na2SO4. And a crude product was obtained by concentratedand evaporated the organic layer in vacuo. "Predict the product for the following reaction: First reactant: CC(C)=O, second reactant: CC=CC=O, Temperature: 30 - 40°C, Time: 6 hours, Catalyst: unknown, Solvent: water. Also the procedure of the reaction was the following: The reaction flask was charged with 639 g (11 mol) of acetone and 500 ml of 8% aqueous sodium hydroxide. The mixture was stirred at room temperature (20-25  C.) for 30 minutes and slowly added to 70.1 g (1 mol) of crotonaldehyde The dropping temperature was controlled between 30-40 . After the completion of the dropwise addition, the reaction was continued at 30-40 for 6 hours. The reaction was completely followed by GC (crotonaldehyde ≤2%) and the reaction solution was cooled to room temperature (20-25 ), 500ml of water and 1000ml of toluene was added and stirred for 30 minutes, allowed to stand for 30 minutes, separated into layers, and then 500ml of water was added to the organic layer and stirred for 30 minutes, allowed to stand for 30 minutes, The organic layer was depressurized and desolvented. Toluene was recovered and applied to give 102.8 g of a light yellow liquid. The purity of the gas phase was 97.8%. The yield of pure organic compound was 91.3%. The SMILES answer is : CC=CC=CC(C)=O

"

"Predict the product for the following reaction: First reactant: CN(=O)=O, second reactant: FC1=CC=C(C=O)C=C1, Temperature: 120°C, Time: unknown hours, Catalyst: unknown, Solvent: unknown. Also the procedure of the reaction was the following: General procedure: To a solution of the appropriate benzaldehyde (3.6 mmol) in glacial acetic acid (4 mL) was added the nitroalkane (7.2mmol) followed by cyclohexylamine (3.6 mmol, 0.4 mL). The reaction mixture was heated under microwave irradiation at 120 C for 30 min. After cooling, water (10 mL) was added to the reaction and it was allowed to stand. The precipitated nitroethene was isolated by filtration. The filtrate was further diluted with water (20 mL) and extracted with dichloromethane (3 x 10 mL). The organic phases were combined and washed with saturated aqueous NaHCO3 (3 x10 mL). The solution was dried over anhydrous Na2SO4, filtered and all solvent removed in vacuo, to give an oil which was purified by flash column chromatography over silica gel (eluent: dichloromethane/hexane) and recrystallised from ethanol. "Predict the product for the following reaction: First reactant: CN(=O)=O, second reactant: FC1=CC=C(C=O)C=C1, Temperature: 20°C, Time: 1 hours, Catalyst: unknown, Solvent: ethanol. Also the procedure of the reaction was the following: General procedure: Equimolar amounts of aryl aldehyde and nitromethane (1. equiv.) were dissolved in 95% ethyl alcohol (100 mL) at room temperature and then a solution of sodium hydroxide (1 equiv.) in ethyl alcohol (30 mL) was added from a dropping funnel at a rate of 5 mL per minute. The solution of the nitromethane and aldehyde in alcohol was then vigorously stirred at room temperature for 1 hour. As the reaction proceeded, the insoluble sodium salt of the condensation product precipitated. After all of the alkali had been added and with the temperature kept below 20 C, ice water (about 30 mL) was slowly added until the precipitate just dissolved. This clear, cold solution was slowly added to a solution of 15% HCl (50 mL) and more cold water (300 mL) was added. A fine, light yellow precipitate was immediately formed and filtered with suction after standing for half an hour. The product thus formed was quite pure and was found to be satisfactory as a starting product for subsequent preparations without further purification. The SMILES answer is : FC1=CC=C(\C=C\N(=O)=O)C=C1

Also the procedure of the reaction was the following: To a solution of lithium bis(trimethylsilyl)amide (1M in THF) (100 mL, 100 mmol) in THF (100 mL) under N2 and cooled to -78 C was added ethyl acetate (9.74 mL, 100 mmol). The reaction mixture was stirred for 30 minutes, and then acetone (8.81 mL, 120 mmol) was added. The reaction mixture was stirred for 10 minutes, and then quenched with HC1 (2 aqueous, 70 mL, 140 mmol) and allowed to warm to ambient temperature. The reaction mixture was extracted with EtOAc (2 x 150 mL). The organic phases were combined and washed with saturated aqueous NaHC03 (2 x 50 mL), dried (MgS04), filtered and concentrated to afford the product as a yellow oil (12.8 g, 88% yield). 1H NMR (CDC13) δ 4.18 (q, 3H), 2.49 (s, 2H), 1.29 (m, 9H). The SMILES answer is : CCOC(=O)CC(C)(C)O

"

"Predict the product for the following reaction: First reactant: O=CC1=CC=CO1, second reactant: CC(=O)C1=CC=CO1, Temperature: 20; 20°C, Time: unknown hours, Catalyst: unknown, Solvent: ethanol; ethanol. Also the procedure of the reaction was the following: General procedure: As shown in Scheme 1 , the required chalcone derivatives (3a-f, 4a-e, 4g, 5a-e, 5h, 6a-f and 6i) were synthesised via aq. KOH catalysed, Claisen-Schmidt condensation reaction [37] between aromatic ketones (1a-d) with the aromatic aldehydes (2a-i) in the ethanol-water medium at room temperature (RT) for 20-24h. To earn the target chalcones, 1eq. of ketone (1a-d) was dissolved in 20eq. of ethanol and stirred for 5min. 10% KOH (1.5eq.) solution was added slowly to the stirring reaction mixture. The reaction mixture was stirred for 15min, and 1eq. of aldehyde (2a-i) dissolved in 20eq. of ethanol was added dropwise. Stirring was continued for 20-24h at RT, and TLC monitored the reaction progress in an 8:2 hexane-EtOAc solvent system. After the reaction completion, excess ethanol in the crude compound was concentrated, and the product was separated from the aqueous fraction by solvent extraction with EtOAc (3 times). The combined EtOAc layer was dried using anhydrous sodium sulphate, and the excess solvent was removed on concentration under vacuum conditions at 45C. The crude product was purified via silica gel column chromatography (silica gel 100-200 mesh size) using the hexane-EtOAc solvent system to earn the chalcones derivatives (3a-f, 4a-e, 4g, 5a-e, 5h, 6a-f and 6i) in 75-94% yields. The products ' starting materials, reaction time, product structure, appearance, yield, and melting point are tabulated in Table 1 . The IR and NMR (1H and 13C) spectrum of the synthesised chalcones are given in the SI file (Table SI 1 and Fig. SI 1-75). The SMILES answer is : O=C(C=CC1=CC=CO1)C1=CC=CO1

"Predict the product for the following reaction: First reactant: O=CC1=CC=CS1, second reactant: CC(=O)C1=CC=CS1, Temperature: 0 - 20°C, Time: unknown hours, Catalyst: unknown, Solvent: ethanol; water. Also the procedure of the reaction was the following: General procedure: General Procedure (GP1). To a mixture of appropriate acetone (1.0 equiv), aldehyde (1.0 equiv) in EtOH at 0 C was added 10 % (w/w) aqueous NaOH (0.15 equiv) gradually. The mixture was allowed to be stirred at room temperature overnight. Large amounts of yellow insoluble product precipitated during the procedure. The precipitation was filtered and washed with water (350 mL) and cold MeOH (310 mL) successively to give product α,β-unsaturated ketone chalcone as a solid. The product was pure enough to be used in the next step without further purification. To a stirred solution of α,β-unsaturated ketone chalcone (1.0 equiv) in MeOH was added CeCl37H2O (1.0 equiv). The solution was cooled to 0 C and NaBH4 (1.1 equiv) was added. The mixture was stirred at room temperature for 1 h before water was added and exacted with CH2Cl2. The combined organic phases were dried with Na2SO4, and the solvents evaporated under vacuum. The pure compound was obtained after flash chromatography on silica gel. Physical and spectroscopic data are given below. For known compounds, only 1H/13C NMR data are listed. The SMILES answer is : O=C(C=CC1=CC=CS1)C1=CC=CS1

"

Also the procedure of the reaction was the following: 1,3,-di-thiophen-2-yl-propenone was prepared through aldol-condensation reaction of 2-acetyl thiophene and thiophene-2-carbaldehyde in diethylamine and degassed water. The SMILES answer is : O=C(C=CC1=CC=CS1)C1=CC=CS1

"Predict the product for the following reaction: First reactant: O=CC1=CC=CS1, second reactant: CC(=O)C1=CC=CS1, Temperature: 0°C, Time: unknown hours, Catalyst: unknown, Solvent: methanol; methanol. Also the procedure of the reaction was the following: Take compound (3a) (20mmol, 2.24g),20ml of 85% KOH solution (85% KOH solution is prepared by dissolving 1.32g KOH in 5ml of water and 30ml of MeOH), the two were mixed and reacted at 0 C. After 10 min, 2.33 ml of compound (2a) (21.6 mmol, 2.72 g) was added thereto, stirred in an ice bath for 3 h, and then filtered to obtain a filter residue. The filter residue was washed with 40 mmol of cold methanol, and dried in vacuo to obtain 4.2 g of light yellow crystals, which was compound (4a), with a yield of 90%. The SMILES answer is : O=C(C=CC1=CC=CS1)C1=CC=CS1

"
"Predict the product for the following reaction: First reactant: O=CC1=CC=CS1, second reactant: CC(=O)C1=CC=CS1, Temperature: 25°C, Time: unknown hours, Catalyst: unknown, Solvent: ethanol; water. Also the procedure of the reaction was the following: Weigh 12 mmol of 2-acetylthiophene and 24 mmol of thiophene aldehyde and dissolve them in 120 mL of ethanol. Slowly add 30 mL of 10% sodium hydroxide aqueous solution and react at 25C for 13 hours. The reaction is completed. Afterwards, it was suction filtered, and the filter cake was washed with deionized water and dried under vacuum at 120C to obtain a yellow solid, which was recorded as compound E. The SMILES answer is : O=C(C=CC1=CC=CS1)C1=CC=CS1

"Predict the product for the following reaction: First reactant: O=CC1=CC=CS1, second reactant: CC(=O)C1=CC=CS1, Temperature: 20; 20°C, Time: unknown hours, Catalyst: unknown, Solvent: ethanol; ethanol. Also the procedure of the reaction was the following: General procedure: As shown in Scheme 1 , the required chalcone derivatives (3a-f, 4a-e, 4g, 5a-e, 5h, 6a-f and 6i) were synthesised via aq. KOH catalysed, Claisen-Schmidt condensation reaction [37] between aromatic ketones (1a-d) with the aromatic aldehydes (2a-i) in the ethanol-water medium at room temperature (RT) for 20-24h. To earn the target chalcones, 1eq. of ketone (1a-d) was dissolved in 20eq. of ethanol and stirred for 5min. 10% KOH (1.5eq.) solution was added slowly to the stirring reaction mixture. The reaction mixture was stirred for 15min, and 1eq. of aldehyde (2a-i) dissolved in 20eq. of ethanol was added dropwise. Stirring was continued for 20-24h at RT, and TLC monitored the reaction progress in an 8:2 hexane-EtOAc solvent system. After the reaction completion, excess ethanol in the crude compound was concentrated, and the product was separated from the aqueous fraction by solvent extraction with EtOAc (3 times). The combined EtOAc layer was dried using anhydrous sodium sulphate, and the excess solvent was removed on concentration under vacuum conditions at 45C. The crude product was purified via silica gel column chromatography (silica gel 100-200 mesh size) using the hexane-EtOAc solvent system to earn the chalcones derivatives (3a-f, 4a-e, 4g, 5a-e, 5h, 6a-f and 6i) in 75-94% yields. The products ' starting materials, reaction time, product structure, appearance, yield, and melting point are tabulated in Table 1 . The IR and NMR (1H and 13C) spectrum of the synthesised chalcones are given in the SI file (Table SI 1 and Fig. SI 1-75). The SMILES answer is : O=C(C=CC1=CC=CS1)C1=CC=CS1

"
"Predict the product for the following reaction: First reactant: O=CC1=CC=CS1, second reactant: CC(C)=O, Temperature: 70°C, Time: 2.5 hours, Catalyst: unknown, Solvent: water. Also the procedure of the reaction was the following: [0068] Preparation of Compound III (78; SRI-22933). 2-Thiophenecarboxaldehyde (7; 40 mmol, 4.8 ml) was taken in acetone (6 ml), water (8 ml) and 1% NaOH (10 ml). This mixture was heated at 70C for 2.5 hours. The mixture was poured into H20 (100 ml) and extracted with chloroform which was evaporated to dryness to give the intermediate chalcone (8) (6 grams, 99% yield). The SMILES answer is : CC(=O)C=CC1=CC=CS1

"Predict the product for the following reaction: First reactant: O=CC1=CC=CS1, second reactant: CC(C)=O, Temperature: 20°C, Time: unknown hours, Catalyst: unknown, Solvent: water. Also the procedure of the reaction was the following: General procedure: To an Erlenmeyer flask containing a solution of 2-furan or 2-thiophen carboxaldehyde (50 mmol) in acetone/water 2:1 (15 mL) under ice bath was added aqueous solution of NaOH (2.5 mL of 10% w/w aqueous solution) dropwise. The resulting solution was kept under stirring at room temperature until consume of starting material. Then, aqueous HCl was added dropwise to the solution until pH 4 followed by extraction with CH2Cl2 (2×15 mL). Organic layers were washed with aqueous solution of NaHCO3 and brine and then dried over Na2SO4. The media was concentrated in rotary evaporator and the crude purified by distillation under vacuum in a kugelrohr device. The SMILES answer is : CC(=O)C=CC1=CC=CS1

"
"Predict the product for the following reaction: First reactant: O=CC1=CC=CS1, second reactant: CC(C)=O, Temperature: 20 - 65°C, Time: unknown hours, Catalyst: unknown, Solvent: water. Also the procedure of the reaction was the following: General procedure: Substituted benzaldehydes (10 mmol, 1.0 eq) were dissolved in a mixture of acetoneand water, 1% aqueous NaOH (10 mL) was slowly added to the reaction mixture, andthe reaction mixture was heated from room temperature to 65C and stirred uniformlyuntil TLC detection. The reaction of the starting materials was completed. The reactionmixture was cooled to room temperature. A mixture of ethyl acetate (20 mL) and water(10 mL) was added to the round bottom flask, and the organic phase was extracted andseparated. The organic phase was washed with saturated NaCl, dried over anhydrousNa2SO4, and concentrated under reduced pressure. The α, β-unsaturated ketones withdifferent substituents were obtained by column chromatography on silica gel (~75%yield) The SMILES answer is : CC(=O)C=CC1=CC=CS1

"Predict the product for the following reaction: First reactant: CC1=CC=C(O1)C=O, second reactant: CC(=O)C1=CC=C(Cl)C=C1, Temperature: 0 - 25°C, Time: 24 hours, Catalyst: unknown, Solvent: ethanol; water. Also the procedure of the reaction was the following: General procedure: A mixture of 5-methyl-2-furaldehyde (21.72 mmol) with substituted acetophenone (21.72mmol) was dissolved in absolute ethanol (20 mL). Slowly, aqueous NaOH solution (4.3 mL,2%) was added drop-wise [12] at 0C and stirred for 24 hr at 25C. After the completion ofreaction was tested on pre-coated TLC plates, ice water (100 mL) was added and neutralizedwith 10% HCl. The precipitate formed was collected by vacuum filtration, washed with coldwater, dried, and recrystallized using ethanol. The SMILES answer is : CC1=CC=C(O1)C=CC(=O)C1=CC=C(Cl)C=C1

"
"Predict the product for the following reaction: First reactant: CC1=CC=C(O1)C=O, second reactant: CC(=O)C1=CC=C(Cl)C=C1, Temperature: 0°C, Time: 24 hours, Catalyst: unknown, Solvent: ethanol; water. Also the procedure of the reaction was the following: The experimental procedure for this reaction followed thepublished method [12]. Substituted aromatic ketone (2) (20 mmol)and 5-methyl-2furaldehyde (1) (20 mmol) were dissolved in absoluteethanol (20 ml) and cooled to 0 C in ice bath. Aqueous sodiumhydroxide solution (2%, 4 ml) was added dropwise to thereaction mixture and stirred for 24 h. The completion of reactionwas tested on precoated TLC plates. The reaction mixture was poured into ice-water (100 ml) and neutralized with 10% HCl. Theprecipitated formed was collected by vacuum filtration, washedwith coldwater, dried and recrystallized using ethanol. Similar typeof chalcone derivatives was synthesized by Ahmad et al. [19]. The SMILES answer is : CC1=CC=C(O1)C=CC(=O)C1=CC=C(Cl)C=C1

"
"Predict the product for the following reaction: First reactant: CC1=CC=C(O1)C=O, second reactant: CC(=O)C1=CC=C(Cl)C=C1, Temperature: 0 - 5°C, Time: unknown hours, Catalyst: unknown, Solvent: methanol. Also the procedure of the reaction was the following: 0.02mol of 4-chloroacetophenone was dissolved in 20mL of anhydrous methanol, and 15mL of 10% NaOH solution was added thereto. With stirring in an ice bath, a mixture of 0.02 mol 5-methylfurfural and 20 mL of anhydrous methanol was slowly dropped into the above mixed solution with a constant pressure dropping funnel, reacted at 0 to 5  C, and a thin-layer silica gel plate (TLC) check if the reaction is complete. After the reaction is complete, add 3 to 4 volumes of distilled water to the mixture, and adjust its pH value to neutral with 10% HCl, precipitate out, filter, wash, and recrystallize with absolute ethanol to obtain chalcone. Intermediate. The SMILES answer is : CC1=CC=C(O1)C=CC(=O)C1=CC=C(Cl)C=C1

"
"Predict the product for the following reaction: First reactant: CC1=CC=C(O1)C=O, second reactant: CC(=O)C1=CC=C(Cl)C=C1, Temperature: 0 - 5°C, Time: unknown hours, Catalyst: unknown, Solvent: ethanol. Also the procedure of the reaction was the following: Dissolve 10 mmol of 4-chloroacetophenone in 10 mL of absolute ethanol, and then add 10 mL of 10% NaOH ethanol solution to it. Stir in an ice bath, slowly drip the mixed solution of 10mmol 5-methylfuran-2-carboxaldehyde and 10mL of absolute ethanol into the above mixed solution with a constant pressure dropping funnel, react at 05, and use thinner Layer silica gel plate (TLC) to check whether the reaction is complete. After the reaction is completed, add 10 times the volume of distilled water to the mixed solution, adjust the pH value of the solution to neutral with a 10% hydrochloric acid solution, precipitate precipitation, filter, and wash with distilled water. The obtained crude product was recrystallized with absolute ethanol to obtain the chalcone intermediate. The SMILES answer is : CC1=CC=C(O1)C=CC(=O)C1=CC=C(Cl)C=C1

"
"Predict the product for the following reaction: First reactant: CC1=CC=C(O1)C=O, second reactant: CC(=O)C1=CC=C(Cl)C=C1, Temperature: 0 - 5°C, Time: unknown hours, Catalyst: unknown, Solvent: ethanol. Also the procedure of the reaction was the following: Dissolve 10mmol 4-chloroacetophenone in 10mL absolute ethanol,Then 10 mL of 10% NaOH ethanol solution was added to it.Stir in an ice bath,Slowly drip the mixed solution of 10mmol 5-methylfuran-2-carboxaldehyde and 10mL of absolute ethanol into the above mixed solution with a constant pressure dropping funnel.React at 05,And use a thin layer silica gel plate (TLC) to check whether the reaction is complete.After the reaction is completed, add 10 times the volume of distilled water to the mixed solution,Adjust the pH of the solution to neutral with 10% hydrochloric acid solution,A precipitate precipitated out, filtered, and washed with distilled water.The obtained crude product was recrystallized with absolute ethanol to obtain the chalcone intermediate. The SMILES answer is : CC1=CC=C(O1)C=CC(=O)C1=CC=C(Cl)C=C1

"
"Predict the product for the following reaction: First reactant: CC1=CC=C(O1)C=O, second reactant: CC(=O)C1=CC=C(Cl)C=C1, Temperature: 0 - 5°C, Time: unknown hours, Catalyst: unknown, Solvent: ethanol. Also the procedure of the reaction was the following: General procedure: In accordance with Scheme 1, selected 4-substituted acetophenone (10 mmol) was dissolved in anhydrous ethanol (10 mL). NaOH anhydrous ethanol solution (10%, 5 mL) was added to the solution. The mixture of selected aldehyde (10 mmol) and anhydrous ethanol (10 mL) was slowly added to the above solution in an ice box under stirring. The reaction was kept at 0-5 C for 3-5 h and monitored by thin layer chromatography (TLC). After completion, the reaction mixture was poured into ice water and neutralized by HCl (10%) till the solution became neutral. The solid that precipitated was filtered and washed with distilled water. The crude products were recrystallized from anhydrous ethanol/dichloromethane (v/v = 1:1) to give intermediate 1 in the yield exceeding 90%. In order to obtain enough intermediate 1 (from 10 mmol to 30 mmol) for the subsequent synthesis of compounds 2 and 3, the synthesis of intermediate 1 was repeated several times. The SMILES answer is : CC1=CC=C(O1)C=CC(=O)C1=CC=C(Cl)C=C1

"
"Predict the product for the following reaction: First reactant: CC1=CC=C(O1)C=O, second reactant: CC(=O)C1=CC=C(Cl)C=C1, Temperature: 0 - 5°C, Time: unknown hours, Catalyst: unknown, Solvent: ethanol. Also the procedure of the reaction was the following: General procedure: As shown in Scheme 2, selected acetophenone compound(0.01mol) was dissolved in anhydrous ethanol (10 mL)completely. 10% NaOH anhydrous ethanol solution (5 mL)was added to the mixture with stirring in an ice bath (0~5 C).The solution of furan aldehyde or thiophene aldehyde(0.01mol) and anhydrous ethanol (10mL) was dropwiseadded into the above mixture. The reaction was carried outunder constant temperature and was monitored by thin-layer chromatography (TLC). After reaction completion, appropriatedistilled water was added, and the pH value of thereaction mixture was adjusted to neutral by 10% HCl solution.Amount of solid was separated out subsequently. Thesolid was filtered out and washed with distilled water forseveral times. The crude product was recrystallized withanhydrous ethanol or the mixture solvent of anhydrousethanol and dichloromethane, thus the chalcone intermediateswere obtained and their yields ranged from 90 to 95%. The SMILES answer is : CC1=CC=C(O1)C=CC(=O)C1=CC=C(Cl)C=C1

"

Also the procedure of the reaction was the following: General procedure: In accordance with Scheme 1, selected 4-substituted acetophenone (10 mmol) was dissolved in anhydrous ethanol (10 mL). NaOH anhydrous ethanol solution (10%, 5 mL) was added to the solution. The mixture of selected aldehyde (10 mmol) and anhydrous ethanol (10 mL) was slowly added to the above solution in an ice box under stirring. The reaction was kept at 0-5 C for 3-5 h and monitored by thin layer chromatography (TLC). After completion, the reaction mixture was poured into ice water and neutralized by HCl (10%) till the solution became neutral. The solid that precipitated was filtered and washed with distilled water. "Predict the product for the following reaction: First reactant: CC(=O)C1=CC=CC=N1, second reactant: COC1=CC=C(C=O)C=C1, Temperature: 0; 0 - 20°C, Time: 0.166667; 0.166667 hours, Catalyst: unknown, Solvent: ethanol; water; ethanol; water. Also the procedure of the reaction was the following: General procedure: To a stirred solution of 2-acetylpyridine (0.100mL, 0.108g, 0.890mmol), for example, in EtOH (2.5mL) was added aqueous 8M KOH (1-6 equivalent). This mixture was stirred at 0C for 10 min, followed by addition of the corresponding aldehyde (1.5 equivalent) dropwise at the same temperature. The mixture was gradually warmed up to room temperature until 2-acetylpyridine was completely consumed according to TLC analysis. At the end of the reaction time, the mixture was quenched by 2N HCl, diluted with H2O and extracted with CH2Cl2. Method A: The organic layer was dried over MgSO4 and purified by flash column chromatography. The SMILES answer is : COC1=CC=C(\C=C\C(=O)C2=NC=CC=C2)C=C1

"Predict the product for the following reaction: First reactant: CC(=O)C1=CC=CC=N1, second reactant: COC1=CC=C(C=O)C=C1, Temperature: 20°C, Time: 12 hours, Catalyst: unknown, Solvent: methanol. Also the procedure of the reaction was the following: General procedure: Referring to the literature 9b by a modified method, to a solutionof 2-acetyl pyridine (20 mmol) and aldehyde (20 mmol) in methanol (60 mL) was added to KOH (20 mmol) and H2O (2 mL) at ambient temperature. The resulting solution was stirred at room temperature for 12 h. Then H2O (1000 mL) was added,filtered under reduced the pressure, dried to obtain the crude product. The crude product was purified by column chromatography over silicagel with EtOAc/n-Hexane (1:10) as eluant, affording the chalcones containing pyridine (1a~1m). The SMILES answer is : COC1=CC=C(\C=C\C(=O)C2=NC=CC=C2)C=C1

"
"Predict the product for the following reaction: First reactant: CC(=O)C1=CC=CC=N1, second reactant: COC1=CC=C(C=O)C=C1, Temperature: unknown°C, Time: 2 hours, Catalyst: unknown, Solvent: methanol; water. Also the procedure of the reaction was the following: MPP was synthesized by Claisen-Schimidt condensation reaction [13]. To synthesize 3-(4-Methoxyphenyl)-1-(pyridin-2-yl)prop-2-en-1-one, commercially available Analytical Reagent (AR) grade chemicals were used without further purification. The starting compounds, 2-Acetyl pyridine (0.01 mol) and 4-methoxy benzaldehyde (0.01 mol) were dissolved in methanol (60 ml). Sodium hydroxide (5 ml, 20%) was then added to this solution, and stirred for 2 h. The content of the flask were poured into ice-cold water and the resulting crude solid was collected by filtration and dried. The light yellow colour compound obtained was re-crystallized twice from acetone solution. During the recrystallization the mother solution was treated with activated charcoal and filtered solution was subjected to rapid crystallization. The synthetic scheme for the title compound is shown in Fig. 1. The SMILES answer is : COC1=CC=C(\C=C\C(=O)C2=NC=CC=C2)C=C1

"
"Predict the product for the following reaction: First reactant: CC(=O)C1=CC=CC=N1, second reactant: COC1=CC=C(C=O)C=C1, Temperature: 5 - 20°C, Time: unknown hours, Catalyst: unknown, Solvent: methanol; ethanol. Also the procedure of the reaction was the following: General procedure: Equimolar portions of the appropriately substituted aryl aldehydes(10 mmol) and ketones (10 mmol, 1equiv) were dissolved in approximately 25 mL of ethanol. The mixture was allowed to stir for 30 min at5-10 C. 1 mL aliquot of a 10% methanolic sodium hydroxide solution was added dropwise to the reaction mixture. The reaction solution was allowed to stir at room temperature for approximately 4-10 h. Progress of the reaction was monitored via TLC. After completion of the reaction,excess of solvent was evaporated from the mixture using rotary evaporator.Chilled water was poured into the reaction mixture and precipitatesof intermediate chalcones were filtered and dried. The crude product was then recrystallized from ethanol to get pure chalcones. The SMILES answer is : COC1=CC=C(\C=C\C(=O)C2=NC=CC=C2)C=C1

"Predict the product for the following reaction: First reactant: CC(=O)C1=CC=CO1, second reactant: CC1=CC=C(C=O)C=C1, Temperature: 20°C, Time: 0.333333 hours, Catalyst: unknown, Solvent: methanol. Also the procedure of the reaction was the following: General procedure: The condensation reaction was carried out by reactingan equimolar mixture of aromatic benzaldehydeand acetophenone or 2-acetylfuran in methanol inthe presence of KF-modifi ed clay (30 mg) at roomtemperature (Scheme 1). The progress of the reactionis monitored by thin-layer chromatography everyfi ve minutes. At the end of the reaction, the productprecipitates. It is then taken up in dichloromethane (2 ×10 mL). The organic phase is dried over Na2SO4 andthe solvent is evaporated using a rotary evaporator. Theproduct is then purifi ed by recrystallization from ethanoland characterized by FTIR, 1H NMR, and 13C NMR. The SMILES answer is : CC1=CC=C(C=CC(=O)C2=CC=CO2)C=C1

"Predict the product for the following reaction: First reactant: CC(=O)C1=CC=CO1, second reactant: CC1=CC=C(C=O)C=C1, Temperature: 20°C, Time: 0.25 hours, Catalyst: unknown, Solvent: ethanol. Also the procedure of the reaction was the following: General procedure: The compounds 3(a-h) which are chalcones were produced by base-catalyzed Claisen Schmidt condensation reaction. A blend of substituted benzaldehydes (1a-h, 0.01 mol) and 1-(furan-2-yl) ethan-1-one (2, 0.01 mol) in 10 ml ethanol was stimulated for 15 min at normal temperature. At that point, NaOH 10% solution (1 g in 10 ml of ethanol) was added with stirring to the reaction combination. After vivacious mixing for 3-4 h, the reaction was checked by TLC using running solvent system of hexane: ethyl acetate (3:1). On completion of the process, the mixture was filled into super cold water inclosing 2 ml of concentrated HCl [ 28 , 29 ]. The isolated solid was filtered and washed with super cold wa- ter. At that point, it was dehydrated to acquire an unrefined item which on recrystallization with ethanol managed the cost of the unadulterated mixtures 3(a-h). The SMILES answer is : CC1=CC=C(C=CC(=O)C2=CC=CO2)C=C1

"

"Predict the product for the following reaction: First reactant: CC(=O)C1=CC=CO1, second reactant: CC1=CC=C(C=O)C=C1, Temperature: 20 - 25°C, Time: 6 hours, Catalyst: unknown, Solvent: methanol; water. Also the procedure of the reaction was the following: General procedure: An aqueous solution of sodium hydroxide (20%, 10 mL) was added slowly to the stirring solution of the appropriate aryl aldehyde (1 mmol) and appropriate acetophenone (1 mmol) in methanol (20 mL) in 100 mL conical flask. The stirring was continued for 6 h, keeping the temperature of reaction mixture between 20 and 25 C. The reaction mixture was then poured into ice cold water (100 mL). It was then neutralized with hydrochloric acid (5%). A yellow solid was obtained after filtration which was recrystallized from ethanol and was used further for the next step. "Predict the product for the following reaction: First reactant: CC(=O)C1=CC=CO1, second reactant: CC1=CC=C(C=O)C=C1, Temperature: unknown°C, Time: unknown hours, Catalyst: unknown, Solvent: ethanol; water. Also the procedure of the reaction was the following: General procedure: Chalcones were synthesized by stirring the appropriate aldehydes and active hydrogen ketones in ethanol, with a few drops of aq. NaOH (50%). The target chalcones were precipitated and subsequently underwent filtration and recrystallization from EtOH to give pure compounds [18]. 4-Amino-1,2,4-triazole-3-thione derivative 1 was prepared according to the procedures [22]. "Predict the product for the following reaction: First reactant: CC(=O)C1=CC=CO1, second reactant: CC1=CC=C(C=O)C=C1, Temperature: 60°C, Time: unknown hours, Catalyst: unknown, Solvent: ethanol. Also the procedure of the reaction was the following: General procedure: A mixture of 2-Acetyl Furan (0.01 mol) and appropriate aldehydes (0.01mol) was dissolved in minimum quantity of alcohol. Heat the reaction mixture at about 60 C and then add 40% NaOH slowly with constant stirring about 45 minutes. Keep the mixture overnight and then pour in to ice cold water and if necessary then acidify with dil. HCl, the solid chalcone obtained. Filter it and recrystallized by ethyl alcohol. Determine its Melting point. TLC used to check the purity of each synthesized using n-Hexane and Ethyl acetate (6:4) as a solvent system. The SMILES answer is : CC1=CC=C(C=CC(=O)C2=CC=CO2)C=C1

"
"Predict the product for the following reaction: First reactant: CC(=O)C1=CC=CO1, second reactant: CC1=CC=C(C=O)C=C1, Temperature: 20; 20°C, Time: unknown hours, Catalyst: unknown, Solvent: ethanol; ethanol. Also the procedure of the reaction was the following: General procedure: As shown in Scheme 1 , the required chalcone derivatives (3a-f, 4a-e, 4g, 5a-e, 5h, 6a-f and 6i) were synthesised via aq. KOH catalysed, Claisen-Schmidt condensation reaction [37] between aromatic ketones (1a-d) with the aromatic aldehydes (2a-i) in the ethanol-water medium at room temperature (RT) for 20-24h. To earn the target chalcones, 1eq. of ketone (1a-d) was dissolved in 20eq. of ethanol and stirred for 5min. 10% KOH (1.5eq.) solution was added slowly to the stirring reaction mixture. The reaction mixture was stirred for 15min, and 1eq. of aldehyde (2a-i) dissolved in 20eq. of ethanol was added dropwise. Stirring was continued for 20-24h at RT, and TLC monitored the reaction progress in an 8:2 hexane-EtOAc solvent system. After the reaction completion, excess ethanol in the crude compound was concentrated, and the product was separated from the aqueous fraction by solvent extraction with EtOAc (3 times). The combined EtOAc layer was dried using anhydrous sodium sulphate, and the excess solvent was removed on concentration under vacuum conditions at 45C. The crude product was purified via silica gel column chromatography (silica gel 100-200 mesh size) using the hexane-EtOAc solvent system to earn the chalcones derivatives (3a-f, 4a-e, 4g, 5a-e, 5h, 6a-f and 6i) in 75-94% yields. The products ' starting materials, reaction time, product structure, appearance, yield, and melting point are tabulated in Table 1 . The IR and NMR (1H and 13C) spectrum of the synthesised chalcones are given in the SI file (Table SI 1 and Fig. SI 1-75). The SMILES answer is : CC1=CC=C(C=CC(=O)C2=CC=CO2)C=C1

"
"Predict the product for the following reaction: First reactant: CC(=O)C1=CC=CO1, second reactant: ClC1=CC=C(C=O)C=C1, Temperature: 20°C, Time: 0.333333 hours, Catalyst: unknown, Solvent: methanol. Also the procedure of the reaction was the following: General procedure: The condensation reaction was carried out by reactingan equimolar mixture of aromatic benzaldehydeand acetophenone or 2-acetylfuran in methanol inthe presence of KF-modifi ed clay (30 mg) at roomtemperature (Scheme 1). The progress of the reactionis monitored by thin-layer chromatography everyfi ve minutes. At the end of the reaction, the productprecipitates. It is then taken up in dichloromethane (2 ×10 mL). The organic phase is dried over Na2SO4 andthe solvent is evaporated using a rotary evaporator. Theproduct is then purifi ed by recrystallization from ethanoland characterized by FTIR, 1H NMR, and 13C NMR. The SMILES answer is : ClC1=CC=C(C=CC(=O)C2=CC=CO2)C=C1

"Predict the product for the following reaction: First reactant: CC(=O)C1=CC=CO1, second reactant: ClC1=CC=C(C=O)C=C1, Temperature: 20°C, Time: 4 hours, Catalyst: unknown, Solvent: water. Also the procedure of the reaction was the following: General procedure: To a solution mixture of1-(furan-2-yl)ethanone,1(0.01 mol) and aromatic aldehydes,2(a-h)(0.01 mol) in methyl alcohol (20 mL), an aqueous solution of potassium hydroxide (0.02 mol) was added. Then the mixture was stirred at room temperature for 4 h, the progress of the reaction was monitored by TLC. After completion, the reaction mixture was transferred into ice-cold water (200 mL) and kept overnight in the refrigerator. The solid formed was filtered and washed thoroughly with ice cold water. The crude product obtained was recrystallized from ethyl alcohol to obtain the compounds,3(a-h). The SMILES answer is : ClC1=CC=C(C=CC(=O)C2=CC=CO2)C=C1

"

"Predict the product for the following reaction: First reactant: CC(=O)C1=CC=CO1, second reactant: COC1=CC=C(C=O)C=C1, Temperature: 20; 20°C, Time: unknown hours, Catalyst: unknown, Solvent: ethanol; ethanol. Also the procedure of the reaction was the following: General procedure: As shown in Scheme 1 , the required chalcone derivatives (3a-f, 4a-e, 4g, 5a-e, 5h, 6a-f and 6i) were synthesised via aq. KOH catalysed, Claisen-Schmidt condensation reaction [37] between aromatic ketones (1a-d) with the aromatic aldehydes (2a-i) in the ethanol-water medium at room temperature (RT) for 20-24h. To earn the target chalcones, 1eq. of ketone (1a-d) was dissolved in 20eq. of ethanol and stirred for 5min. 10% KOH (1.5eq.) solution was added slowly to the stirring reaction mixture. The reaction mixture was stirred for 15min, and 1eq. of aldehyde (2a-i) dissolved in 20eq. of ethanol was added dropwise. Stirring was continued for 20-24h at RT, and TLC monitored the reaction progress in an 8:2 hexane-EtOAc solvent system. After the reaction completion, excess ethanol in the crude compound was concentrated, and the product was separated from the aqueous fraction by solvent extraction with EtOAc (3 times). The combined EtOAc layer was dried using anhydrous sodium sulphate, and the excess solvent was removed on concentration under vacuum conditions at 45C. The crude product was purified via silica gel column chromatography (silica gel 100-200 mesh size) using the hexane-EtOAc solvent system to earn the chalcones derivatives (3a-f, 4a-e, 4g, 5a-e, 5h, 6a-f and 6i) in 75-94% yields. The products ' starting materials, reaction time, product structure, appearance, yield, and melting point are tabulated in Table 1 . The IR and NMR (1H and 13C) spectrum of the synthesised chalcones are given in the SI file (Table SI 1 and Fig. SI 1-75). The SMILES answer is : COC1=CC=C(C=CC(=O)C2=CC=CO2)C=C1
